description:
I made myself a promise awhile ago that I strongly wanted to go to KitTea Cat Café right off the bucket list of future visits, and here I was on Halloween.  I thought I would start on Thursday for a happy meowr for $15; unfortunately, the staff moved it to Wednesday at a different time schedule.  They gotta be kitten me!

Inside a special theme café, there's a cat lounge on the left side, and a modern café at my right side.  If I want what's interesting and adventurous, petting many different types of cats was a remarkable experience.  Well, it's a good thing I paid $20 in advance, but I would never missed an opportunity on a next day.  

It's so much fun to give each cat a gentle rub while enjoying free glass of water or tea in the cat lounge.  It's never that easy to have a cat on my lap.  Only one cat was approachable enough to pounce on my shoulders, and that's Belle.  This female furball sure gives me a warm welcome.  But that's not the last I see of her.  Just when I wanted to give another cat to walk on my shoulder, Belle quickly pounced right on my shoulders!  THAT was the third time she's giving me her warm fuzzies.  Belle isn't the only cat who surprised me.  When I crouched and gently rubbed the cat I unknowingly bumped into, that orange cat zoomed through my legs and into the wooden hamster wheel.  Didn't see that everyday!

If I were to visit the same café again, I would buy something to drink or eat.  But spending one full hour with cats is a better way to learn from very friendly staff members and customers, knowing cat language by its tail.  I might be back to enjoy the smell of their friendly atmosphere.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Rescue cats rescuing me. This was just the type of stress relief I needed. 

The staff is fantastic and the cats are chill, frisky, or anywhere in between. They added a new carpet while I was there, which made an already inviting area more comfortable. Thank you for existing; I'll be back.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Part of me wants to give this place no stars and part of me says oh yes 4 is ample. Can't help but ponder the absurdity of what has become of our society that we need a place like this. 
Petting kitties and cats whilst having tea. Really? Couldn't you do this at your friends home? When I told people where I'd been they immediately offered their cats and their home and their tea. Free!! 

We all know someone that has cats we can pet. We could even request the music and since presumably these are our friends, we can ask them to be quiet. While we pet. While we sip. 
So why pay $25 for an hour of this privilege? I can make up all kinds of reasons to convince myself how much more zen it is not being emotionally tethered to anything and just letting in the furry love. I could say it's healing to be amongst many so well-socialized kitties that you need not worry that they'll run from you and you'll feel rejected.

The truth is I don't know why it's here. Part cool hip millennial factor part zen-out space where the warm kitties nesting in your lap feels transcendental. What? I'm teaching now. 

Dissecting this experience any more is wasteful. If you're curious go. Or maybe If you have good friends house sit their critters for a day or two. I don't know. 

The staff were lovely and informative. The space small but chill. The best part for me? That heated toilet seat!! Who knew using the potty and warming your bum at the same time could be so delightful.
author: Peddie A.

description: My little sister and I love KitTea! Not only do they have a ton of kittens to pet, they also have amazing food (WAFFLES) and tea! Even though there is a time limit for petting the cats, it feels like more than enough time with them. Most of the cats are up for adoption, so it's a great way for them to get exposure and into homes. I find KitTea a bit expensive but it's definitely enjoyable to go to every once in a while or to bring out of towners.
author: Sydney G.

description:
Best place for all you cat and tea lovers. This place is great, they have delicious tea and a few pastries, best of all the have 8 resident cats and 4 for adoption, this changes as cats come and go. If you make a reservation you will get to play with the lovely cats while enjoying a complimentary cup of tea. You can also just come for a cup of tea and watch these silly cats play through a window, it all depends on what you want.

Service is great, these guys are experienced with handling cats and they sure do take great care of them. So if you are looking for something new or if you are looking to adopt this is the place to go.
author: Roman L.

description:
I've had KitTea cafe on my list of places to check out for a long time being a cat lover that I am. I couldn't be happier when I first heard about this cafe opening up in the city. We lucked out as I didn't make reservations, but Ryan was gracious to accommodate us. There are two rooms: there's a small cafe where they serve food and drinks including some delicious hot tea. You can choose from a range of different teas and coffee drinks. I got a cup of hot tea before going into the other room where the kitties are.

Before going into the room where the cats are, they require taking off shoes and sanitizing hands. We got a briefing from one of the staff about how to interact with the cats. The room is kept clean and didn't smell like cat pee which is a plus. The cats have a lot of areas to nap or hide for the skittish ones. The famous cat wheel by the window is well utilized, one of the black and white cats couldn't get enough of it. Cats with collars are up for adoption and the ones without  are resident cats. I would say there were about fifteen or more in the room. 

There is an option to order and eat inside the room with cats, but the staff explained that they cannot serve customers directly due to the strict health code. Instead they have a protocol for customers to pick up there own food at the front desk near the entrance. Free tea refills are available inside the cat room offering four types of Japanese teas to choose from. The staff recommends visiting the cats towards the end of the day near closing time since they are more active just before dinner. They offer a stamp card- visit five times and get the sixth visit free. You know I'll be back!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
The visit here was hit and miss. 

Not a cat lover but I like all animals. The cats there well does normal cat stuff sleeping around cuddling with other cats and yes interacting with the people. Since you are paying 20 per hour make the experience worthy. 

The goal is to have a cat on your lap- I accomplished within the last 5 minutes. +1

Took some nice pictures to share +1

Oh the interior very nice. The sunlight hit against the window... dang good spot for the cats. +1

The $20 it was abit too much but hey it's sf! But again they cannot promise a customer anything with that price- bad or good experience. Talking about refund lol! That, -1

The cat town in Oakland 10/hr they say I will try. 

Also some* adoption and instructions would had been nice esp when kids are allowed! 4 young girls in 3 different sessions arrived with a adult ofc. 
Minus that -1 star. **If*(50/50) kids get terribly hurt who's fault? The cat? 

Don't answer that. 
Not coming back, the neighborhood smell of sh!t p!ss. -1 
But I bow to the owner and employees. (:
author: Linio F.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco for the first time, and even though I was there for a conference, I was trying to do some proper exploring of the city.  I randomly stumbled upon the KitTea Cat Cafe website, thanks to creepy Facebook, and after reading up on them, I decided that was it!  I was making a reservation and stopping in to visit these kitties. 

I arrived a few minutes early for my 12 p.m. reservation, but one of the girls must've seen me standing outside so came to the door and let me in a few minutes early.  After giving me the run down of the place, I ordered my complimentary tea and a delish chocolate chip cookie and headed into the kitty room. 

The "cat wrangler" as she dubbed herself was super sweet, and very knowledgeable of all of the resident, as well as the adoptable cats.  I immediately grabbed a cushion, sat on the ground, and began petting and playing with the friendly felines.  There was plenty of seating, and by the time 12:30 rolled around, there were about 6 of us in the room hanging with the happy cats.  

I think that KitTea Cafe is a genius idea and I wish there were more of them located in the states.  What a brilliant way to rescue street cats, give them a clean, warm, loving home (whether permanent or temporary at the carfe), get them the vet care they need and also give them the opportunity to socialize with humans and other kitties.
author: Danielle W.

description: Cute cat cafe where you get to satisfy all your feline needs. There are plenty of cats to cuddle up to. Try not to bother the sleeping cats too much. How would you feel if you were sleeping and someone keeps waking you up trying to play with you? You can play for a good hour while sipping on tea/eating a snack. The staff here are trained and well-versed in all of the individual cats' behaviors. Environment was calm enough that the cats were sleeping most of the time and not afraid of people. Overall, I thought it was an "okay" experience to try one time.
author: Joanne K.

description:
definitely came here just so I can play with cats! (even though I am more of a dog person) 

I bought tickets online for a 5pm reservation, per person it's about $26.25 to visit the cats for 1 hour (saturday) & free green tea! 

so was it worth it? hmm, YES! this is fur sure a place you need to go once for the experience since there's not many animal themed cafes in cali. 

since we went at 5pm, most of the cats were asleep but they did wake up in the later half of the evening. they're super friendly & playful! the staffs were amazing, they would try to get the cats to interact with us. most of the cats are adoptable too!

I had a purr-fect time there, it was interesting learning the stories of each cats & their personalities. =^ . ^=
author: Ashli C.

description:
This is a fun cat cafe. You get unlimited hot tea which is nice. They have carafes in the room itself so you don't have to leave to get the tea.

The cats were pretty lazy when we went. A lot of them were sleeping. They instantly perk up whenever treats are involved though. Only one of them seemed to be a lap cat, and the rest were uninterested.

The room itself is pretty small. We had about 8-10 people in there and it felt a little cramped. I felt like there weren't enough cats to go around, to be honest!

The assistant was really friendly and basically talked non-stop the entire time about the cats and their fun quirks.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Great place for a Sunday morning. Theres a 10 person capacity so its mellow + bottomless green tea.
The crowd varies from older woman, well mannered kids, a token boyfriend, and usually a crazy cat lady who already has like 10 cats at home. 
Its $25 + extra for food/ non green teas, with vegan options.  
The cafe side is nice to work from with free wifi and not too many people.
author: Gina B.

description:
This is one of the most delightful places to spend an hour or two during your week!  Whether you can't have your own pet cat because you rent in a no-pets building, or you're allergic enough that you can't have one in your space full-time, or you travel too much to be able to maintain your own pet, this is the place for you if you LOVE cats!!!

Entry price ($20/hr weekday, $25/hr weekend) includes bottomless green tea, but for those of us who prefer black tea, you can purchase a pot of that, too!  They also make fancy waffles (savory or sweet!), various desserts (their dark chocolate sea salt cookies are DIVINE!!!), coffee, and hot chocolate.

The employees are all super-friendly and cat-knowledgeable.  They are very accommodating, and make sure you're given all the information you need in order to have the most enjoyable stay in the space!

I applaud their good food/drink hygiene practices:  The people who handle your food and beverages are NOT the same people who handle the cats!  They're very strict about that, and that's very reassuring!

In my experience, the space is 100% WHEELCHAIR-ACCESSIBLE, including the bathroom!!  If you have any issues accessing the space, the employees will immediately jump into action and move anything that needs to be moved in order to facilitate your access! 

The environment is CLEAN!  I'm mildly allergic to cats, but they keep the environment very low-dander, and so I've not had issues sitting in the cat room for the 1 or 2 hours at a time that I've gone.  That said, if you're allergic to cats and don't even want to be in the same room as them, you can still go to the cafe area, order food or tea/coffee/hot chocolate, and watch the cats through the large glass window that makes up one of the walls of the cafe!

Kittea also hosts special events:  yoga with cats, Saturday morning cartoons with cereal and cats, movie nights with cats, etc.!

Most of the cats who live there full-time are black or orange tabbies, and there are always a few temporarily-in-residence cats available for adoption.  Most are very playful and social, although like anyone, sometimes a cat might be having an off day, or be extra sleepy during one of the visiting hours.  Steve, the giant black long-hair is one of the alphas, and is pretty friendly.  Otis is VERY playful, but also being an alpha, tends to boss some of the other cats around.  To me, the sweetest cats are Dolly (fluffy beige-orange, also the oldest in residence, has a special diet so can't eat any cat treats!), Ron (orange tabby with a nub at the end of his tail), and Shiloh (sleek black shorthair).  Pickles, the youngest and newest member of the pack at about 4 months, is a grey and black tabby who has tons of kitten energy, but also loves a good cuddle! 

I've been going here for the past two years or so, and it remains one of the most soothing spaces in what can be a very stressful city!  I've brought my mother-in-law here while she's in town visiting, various friends, and my partner and I sometimes make it part of a date night!  I love this place and heartily recommend it to every cat lover!!!
author: Amy L.

description:
We visited in January 2018 and I really wanted to like this place.  I don't know if it is that we visited first thing in the morning and employees were having a hard time getting in the spirit of things but I didn't get the warm and fuzzies that I see reflected in other reviews here.

First of all, I took my entire family as a special treat.  We, as well as other guests, got situated and ready for cat loving.  The cats weren't the problem. 

It was the lack of monitoring of kids by their parents that were the issue.  Please stay in your lane!

If a cat goes where they prefer and it's not your kid, MOMS!, please don't carry on with your "adult conversation" and ignore what's happening.  You did not pay for other customers to entertain your kids.

We are paying customers, too!  And when your kid is almost sitting on my lap or my own kids' laps trying to get to a cat that chose us, don't act like your kids are the cutest thing and are exempt from respecting other people's spaces and especially, make sure your kids are careful around the food the other guests have ordered.  Damn.

As for this mythical bottomless tea, we didn't get offered much more than one refresh. 

This wasn't my worst experience at a theme cafe but it was definitely one that makes me think twice about making a return visit.
author: General P.

description:
Puns, kitties and tea! What more can you ask for? :P
During our visit to SF, I was treated to a surprise trip to SF's first cat cafe and the first one in the country! Arrive early for check-in, pick up some cute cat socks and put in your order for drinks and/or food. When it is your time to go in, they will ask you to remove your shoes and apply hand sanitizer. There were about 8-10 cats that day. All were friendly and wanting to play. The room was clean and did not smell like cat litter. The only reason I'm not giving this place five stars is because none of the cats wanted to sit on my lap :( Maybe next time we will hide some catnip in our pockets to attract them!
author: Cindy W.

description: I love this place! The cats are so well behaved and happy. The facility is clean and well-maintained too. The complementary Japanese tea is also perfectly brewed. I would definitely return!
author: Jung Ha L.

description:
This was my first visit to KitTea and I was not disappointed.  Expectations were met and exceeded.  The cats were the most affectionate and social I have met.  

  The tea selection was very good and the coconut macaroons were heavenly. Stop by for tea and a snack even if you don't have time to spend with the cats.  They have lots of cat themed gifts as well.  

From the obs-purr-vation window in the cafe you can see the cats playing and napping.

 Everyone that worked there seemed so chill and friendly.  I can't wait to come back again.
author: E. M.

description:
KitTea was a much more memorable experience when compared to other cat cafes in the Bay Area.

For starters, their petting policy is a lot more relaxed--you can have the cats on your lap and pet them while they're sound asleep. Also, the cat lounge members aren't watching you like a hawk throughout the entire experience. 

They also have a cute little cafe where you can watch the cats through the glass window. Their waffles looked pretty good!

Cons: the hour passes by extremely quickly and $25/hr is really pricey. 

Also, the addition of tea was also a nice touch, but I felt that the cups of tea were a bit small and it got a bit tedious asking again and again. Perhaps having multiple pots of tea in the room would make everything easier for everyone.
author: Shirley H.

description: There were a large variety of cats to satisfy everyone. Some cats loved to play, some just wanted to sleep and didn't care about anything happening around them, and some were down to cuddle either on a chair or on the floor. All in all, it was a great experience, and I'm sad I can't take them all home with me :( A purr-fect experience with meow-tastic cats!
author: Meaghan F.

description:
I am a dog AND cat person so any reason to go to a cat cafe will always be welcome. It's not cheating on my cat if I visit the kitties at KitTea Cat Cafe is it? :)

KitTea Cafe is located in Hayes Valley...we got there a quarter to 12 and we waited with others for the cafe to open. When it did, we were asked to go into the cafe to get our cups for tea. In the front of the cafe is the cash wrap with lots of kitty themed merchandise. We took off our shoes and went into the cat room. 

There was a short lecture about how to play with the cats and to recognize behaviors if a cat is overstimulated ex. flicking of tail and also a warning not to rub the bellies of any cat except a ginger called Cheddar who will invite you for belly rubs.

The cats were friendly and loved to be scratched under their chins. My favorite cat was Otis, a white and orange kitty who lounged on a black pillow practically the whole time. A friendly fluffy ginger named Dolly jumped on my lap and decided to make biscuits and suck on my fleece jacket. I felt lucky I was picked! 

The shy cats came out from their hiding places when it was treat time and we were told that they were taught to sit - raise up your hand with the treat in it and they will sit. They were very polite and sat when you asked them to.

It was a great experience going to KitTea Cat Cafe. For those who don't have kitties at home it's a great place to play and be around them. They have a frequent visitor card that when you go 5 times you get a free hour with the kitties. Sounds like a plan to me!
author: Nette T.

description: What a beautiful idea. This place is all smiles and happiness. Wonderful fun with my daughter watching cartoons with 20 cats . Great cafe with especially nice food and drinks . And they help get cars adopted . Wonderful.
author: Ava Q.

description: There is not a single bad thing I can say about the KitTea Cafe. The employees were very kind and friendly, the tea was great, and there were a lot of friendly kitties to play with! My 1 hour was completely worth the $25, and I would definitely come back.
author: Abby L.

description:
Short Story:  A great cate cafe...but it's a hit or miss sometimes.

Long Story:  I've been to this cat cafe twice now.  The first time was fantastic.  I appreciated the cats, their toys, and being able to pet them.  The tea and coffee were good too.

The second time however, was a bit of a different story.  The food was just as good along with the cat toys.  The difference were the cats.  They have bigger cats this time.  They didn't really seem like they wanted to play and most of them kept going to the backroom.

I know it's a risk you take with these cat cafes...after all you can't train the cat exactly like a dog.  But since I had just a good first experience I was really looking forward to going back.  Sadly, one of the cats scratched me and a lot of them didn't want to be picked up.  

I have two cats myself so while I'm not a cat whisper, I certainly know what I'm doing.  But overall it was an okay experience.  The employee inside the play area with us didn't seem too interested in engaging with the cats too.  He brought out the laser pointer towards the last 5 min...which was a bit odd.  I wished he brought it out sooner.  The last time I was there the laser pointers were out so that you could use them yourself.  Maybe someone abused it and had it taken away or something.

Verdict:  I might go back one day...
author: Michael W.

description:
I really enjoyed this cat cafe, and I hope to come back again when they have their egg puffs available on the menu.

The space is divided into 3 rooms: entry which is also a store, the cafe, and the cat space.  You can order your food in the cafe, and it would be brought to the cat space during your visit.  Because of food regulations, you have to get your food as the employees that handle the cats aren't allowed to touch your food.

You're asked to take off your shoes, and you can buy socks if you don't want to be barefoot.  The concrete can be slippery though, so bring non-slip socks.

If you just want to watch, you can sit in the cafe and order your food and beverages.

There's a selection of unlimited teas, and there is an option to upgrade.  You will have to go to the employee in the cat space to place your orders.

My friends and I were there in the afternoon.  Most of the cats were asleep, and one was high on catnip.  I've noticed from going to these cat cafes is that the cats get over stimulated, so they just want to sleep.  If you want more active cats, it's best to make a reservation in the morning.

KitTea also has some cute events, from pajama parties to yoga.  I'd definitely want to try yoga there soon.
author: Vira P.

description:
Pros:
- The place was well decorated.
- Music was calm enough to sustain a conversation.
- Our appointment started in a timely manner.
- Cats had a healthy aspect and did not show aggressive behavior.

Cons:
- Our orders were taken but never came.
- Cats seemed underweight with very palpable ribs and petting them was slightly uncomfortable due to their low weight.
- None of the cats vocalized ("meowed") during the entire duration of the appointment, not even when presented with food, which made me think the cats could be devocalized.
author: Felipe O.

description:
This was the best experience ever. I've always wanted to go to a cat cafe and I finally got to go. First, I ordered food and it was delicious. I mean the salad and sandwich were on par with what I would get at a fancy restaurant. The tea choices were excellent and I loved the flavors. The music was quiet enough but relaxing. When I finally got to spend time with the cats it was heaven. So many cute cats with different personalities. Burger and Strudel were my favorites. Burger sucked on my finger and Strudel hung out on my lap for a bit. 

Basically when I die, I'm pretty sure this is what heaven will look like.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I came here during Mewvie Night to watch Hocus Pocus and I had a blast! This was my first time going to a cat cafe in America and it was pretty similar to the ones in Japan. The cafe is decent sized; there's a little area in the front with cute hand-made cat items, a cafe area for drinking tea and eating and the actual room with kitties. 

There had to be around 10 cats and they were mostly black and orange cats. They were all extremely friendly and playful! I did find it difficult to get one cat to sit with me so I could pet him/her. :( I think maybe that was because they're so used to being pet that they don't need all the attention, but they do love toys so do play with them!! 

All the staff were extremely nice and you could tell they respect the cats and put them first. They were also quick to notice if you wanted to order drinks or food. I will definitely be back to this cafe for their cute cats and their cat merchandise is amazing!
author: Meliza M.

description:
Overpriced for what it is and I do wonder if it's even humane to have the cats allowed so many visitors daily after all. The schedules are booked back to back for the most part. 

Clearly you can tell the cats are rather tired of it. If only cats could talk.

Too many people in one session. Room stinks. Not sure if it's from the feet of visitors or from the cats. Probably both. You're required to talk your shoes off before entering.

I wish they have more exotic looking cats.

Not enough toys for visitors to play with the cats. 

By a certain time, the kitchen is closed and you're left with boring pastries. 

It's one of those places that I would go once and never again. 

Girl at the counter is friendly though. 

My suggestion - Make a visit to a real shelter instead. If there's a cat you like, you can spend one to one time with it before deciding if you'd like to adopt. 

Bonus: $25 on weekends comes with 4 selection of tea but they are not refilled as often. 
 
Bottomline: Blah
author: Nic L.

description:
I'll be honest, this is partially a signal boost because I really like what they do here. It's a neat little, well-organized place that does good work, provides a gratifying experience, and is just a fun spot to go to with family and friends.

To clarify if you don't know what a cat cafe is, it's a cafe that also acts as a shelter, rescue, and sanctuary. I've gone to some Taiwanese and Singaporean cat cafes, and the establishment is usually somewhat split between a cafe (no cats allowed in the cafe), another room where people can go in to eat and play with the cats (this usually has a lot of toys, trees, and perches specifically for them), and a gift shop (though sometimes the gift shop is combined with the cafe). KitTea Cat Cafe has followed this format with a gift shop in the front, a cafe with a window to the cat lounge, and the lounge with a large floor-to-ceiling street window. Love that windows in general, it really makes the space feel open and lets a lot of light in. 

The cafe works like any other kind of cafe. They have coffee, sandwiches, and waffles, but they're most well-known for their all-you-can-drink green tea.There's three different kinds you can choose from; another two if you pay a little extra when ordering. You just go in and sit down to enjoy a coffee, work, write or just watch the cats. Any food you get in the cafe can be brought into the cat room, but there's also menus you can order from in there as well. Physically, the place  isn't that big. It has four small tables kind of crammed together and one long counter space where you can sit at look into the lounge. A number of people seem to like to sit in the cafe just to enjoy the ambiance and look in on the cats. Indeed, it's actually quite a nice spot to hang out, and the employees in the cafe are super accommodating. When I wasn't sure what kind of tea I wanted to try first they just let me sniff at ALL of the available samples (honestly though, they have warm pitchers of the three kinds of free tea inside the cat lounge as well, so you can try most of them). There was also this one girl who had set up in the cafe (laptop, books, just really settled in there). I don't know how long she was there or if she ever went in to see the cats. But she was sitting there when I went in, and still there two hours later. She apparently ordered food for the first time 15 minutes after our hour was up (half our friends were in the next shift), and she was very specific on the kind of bread and cheese she wanted in our grilled cheese sandwich. They don't actually HAVE grilled cheese on their menu, but they got her the grilled cheese anyways. 

If you're planning on settling in the cafe for a few hours, be aware that there's a lot of crowding during that transitioning between appointments when the new group is coming in and the old group are coming out. There's a restroom in both the cafe as well as the cat lounge so you don't have to go outside during your hour, and risk the cats getting out. Additionally, BRING SOCKS. They require it. If you forget, you can buy a pair from the gift shop.

HEADS UP, they will email you a waiver to sign ahead of time, so don't forget that. Like movie theaters, they're cheaper on weekdays, and have a happy hour on Thursdays where it's only $15 an hour per person in comparison to the standard $25 for a Sunday. Additionally, they have these bunch of fun events like movies and yoga, but with cats. I dearly wish I was local enough to try at least one of these.

They have policies that are put in place in order to prevent stressing out the cats. Their foremost measure is to keep too many people from going into the lounge at the time. That's why do RESERVATIONS if you can. Weekend slots get snatched up pretty quickly (it's the reason why my group had to go in two shifts). They do walk-ins, but it's first come first serve and space tends to be limited. If you're going to do this, try the weekdays. Same policy for if you're trying to reserve consecutive hours while in the shop apparently; they'll give it to you if there are slots available. Groups of eight and more require you to book it as another private event altogether. For the same reason, and like most cat cafes, they don't allow small children in. In this case, children under 9. And every child under 12 needs one supervising adult. 

Similar to a lot of escape rooms, cancellations and not showing up are non-refundable. If you want to reschedule, do it days before the actual appointment, because they won't accept same-day changes either. If you arrive late, they won't extend or reschedule.

Ultimately, this is a place where people can interact with cats and relax. I saw a pair of spouses that looked like the most content people ever as they just kinda dosed with each other in the cat lounge. It's a space where you interact, play, and bond with cats in a space they're comfortable. And maybe, later adopt them. Either way, your money is going to a good cause.
author: Christine L.

description:
This place is not just for humans to interact with feline companions, but it's also kitty therapy for those seeking homes and the resident felines. You can enjoy the cafe aside from the cat interaction which is great, plus the teas are truly amazing. It's worth every penny.

I love going at the last slot of the day because the cats seem to be more relaxed and restful after being tired out from the day of play and attention. They offer things like yoga and such, check with them about availability as it gets full fast. 

You also might walk by and not notice it, so keep an eye out and stop in for info and a pleasant time!
author: J Austyn B.

description:
"Grabbing p---y" takes on an extra cringeworthy connotation these days now that we have an illegitimate perv-in-chief inside the White House. Here at KitTea, it just might actually be a positive thing. As opposed to its counterparts in Asia which are cafés that happen to have cats, KitTea feels more like a cat adoption studio that happens to have a café component.

On that note, your experience here can be as cat-immersive as you want. If you're content with viewing the cats from outside a window, you can sip tea and enjoy cookies, waffles, and sandwiches from their café. If you want to frolic with the cats - or, better yet, see if you want to adopt any of them - you can make a reservation for the cat lounge itself. Depending on the time of day, it costs anywhere from $15 to $25 an hour, and includes unlimited refills of their green tea. You can even bring items from the café into the cat area, or order more from within.

As for the cats, the number roaming about, and their playfulness levels, will vary all day long. Some are permanent residents, while some are up for adoption - a certifiably good cause. In any case, the cats are not there to be performance objects, but are instead there to be worshipped by their human subjects. Keep this in mind and you'll have a purr-fect time. ;)
author: Vincent L.

description:
I'm allergic to animal dander, but I was not about to let the prospect of watery, itchy eyes and a runny nose deter me from visiting KitTea Cat Cafe with a fellow cat lover.  We visited on a windy Sunday afternoon and would definitely recommend that you make reservations because they had completely booked all of the sessions that day.  Cat lounge visits are super easy to make online and can be made for every day of the week except for Tuesdays.  Weekends and holidays are typically $25 for a one-hour lounge visit and unlimited cups of green tea, and weekdays are $20.  However, if you're ever free on a Thursday from 3-6 PM there are "Happy Meow'rs" where you can save $5 on your visit.  

Parking can be a little tricky in this area, but we found a metered spot (no meters on Sundays!) two blocks down on Gough after driving around for a bit.  When we arrived, a staff member greeted us at the front and asked if we had a reservation.  We checked in and, since we were a little early, were told that we'd have about ten minutes to wait and could either browse the merchandise or head into the cafe.  The cafe is pretty small and has seating for around 15 people, so my friend and I opted to get started on the Japanese green tea (their genmaicha is delicious!) and browse the merch.  They've got tons of adorable, sassy, cat-themed dishes, cards, stickers, socks, bags, shirts and, get this, cat wine!

When our 4 PM slot rolled around, we were instructed to take off our shoes (socks are recommended but you can go barefoot as well), hang coats on the racks and step inside.  There was a brief introduction and orientation with some ground rules and notes (i.e. photos are ok as long as you don't use flash, there are four carafes with the different Japanese green teas so that you can refill at your leisure, but you can also order food and other drinks through the staff member in the room, etc.).  

I realize that we picked a slot toward the end of the day and the cats were probably all tired of being gawked at.  Many seemed pretty apathetic and others annoyed at all the humans swarming inside.  I'm an introvert and I totally get it, lol, but it can be a little disappointing if you've come with expectations of getting to be around all these affectionate little furballs.    About ten minutes in, the staff member gives out a handful of cat treats to each person and all of a sudden cats start popping out of nowhere and mingling.  I ain't saying they're treat-diggers, but they ain't messing with you if you've got empty hands.  My friend and I were able to hold on to the treats for a while and handed them out one by one to various cats.  Try to lay your hand as flat as possible or you run the risk of getting nipped.  It's also better to show the cats your outstretched, empty palm anyway or some claws might come out as they try to see what you've got in your fist.  

The hour passed by all too quickly and before we knew it it was time to leave.  While there wasn't an overwhelming amount of interaction, the treats definitely helped us get some up-close attention that we might not have otherwise gotten (I've been to the Cat Town cafe in Oakland and wasn't nearly as successful in getting to interact with cats sans treats).  

All in all, I'd definitely come again to hang out with cats, sample their tea selection, and maybe even partake in a special event ("cats on mats" yoga, "mew-vie" nights).  

If you're allergic like I am and worried I'd recommend getting a Costco-sized portion of an over-the-counter antihistamine and you'll be all set!
author: Iona C.

description:
KitTea cafe was my first cat cafe experience. IMO $25 is too pricy for some hot tea and time around cats, especially because the cats are unfriendly until catnip is distributed near the end of the session. 

When the catnip comes out, all the cats became fiends and faught each other for treats. Whyyyy. 

Anyways, the reason for 3 stars instead of 1 are the baby cats who are not in the main room. These 3 cats were separated from the main group until they're "ready" to join them, and they were calm, fun to hang out with, and generally uncorrupted by catnip. 

OK experience, would not do again.
author: Harrison B.

description:
Really cute cafe!! The staff is super friendly. The decor is all very cute and goes along with the theme. We ordered two coffees which each came in these adorable personal sized French presses. We didn't realize that in order to pet the kitties you had to pay $20 dollars for an hour of entry. Totally understandable, as I'm sure they need the funds and donations to take care of the fur babies. I just wish there was maybe an option to do $10 for a half an hour! An hour seems like a bit much, for me at least. 

Nice spot, I really like what they're doing! I hope other places can follow and help spread the promotion to adopt.
author: Maria M.

description:
ehh this place is more for the ambience and set up they have going with cats around. But they should up their food game. It's a bit limited and pricey.

The cat room is visible from the dining area that's separate so you could still get to kind of experience it. There's a ton of cat themed stuff in the fromt entrance area so if you have a friend who loves cat stuff then I would shop there for little gifts. There isn't much seating in the dining area, it's shaped like a cube and holds about 10-15 people at most I think. But nice set up, I liked the trendy decor chosen but the seats kind of dip which is not really my style but different! 

Still pretty cool idea to have a separate room to interact with animals and the milk tea was the good stuff, no powder used here.
author: Laura Y.

description:
The Kittea Cafe should feel very lucky that their cats weren't kidnapped by myself and my fiance, also known as the feline bandits by our friends whose cats we always covet when visiting their houses.  The only reason the cats were not kidnapped was because it would have been quite the fiasco having to ship them back to Chicago where we live.  Like I said, they should feel lucky that geography safeguarded their fluffies from us, kitty officionados.  Though we couldn't take the kittens with us, the hour we spent with them was the highlight of our vacation, if not our year...like, we are the definition of crazy cat people.

If you are a cat person and you like tea, then you need to get here to the Kittea Cafe right away.  There's about 10 different cats that you can play with, and though some are more anti-social than others, most are spunky and will nuzzle with you.  If you truly find yourself attached to one then it is possible to see if you can adopt he/she, though there are some cats that are long-term "residents".  You spend so much of the reserved hour playing with and adoring the cats that you almost forget aboutbthe bottomless tea that is a part of your reservation.  

There's 4 different bottomless tea that you can choose from, but then there's other tea and food you can order however, that's not included in your reservation.  My advice, don't order anything extra - you're already going to be overly involved with petting that cats, there's not enough time to pay attention to food.  Like I've been saying: each reservation you make lasts for an hour, and it's  $25 each hour.  Is it worth it, though?  Hell yeah.  Purrrr's before grrrrr's.  

Hmm, what else should I tell you about this purrrrrrfect establishment?  Well, you must take your shoes off to enter so if you don't want to be a barefooted feline, wear socks.  Also, the staff here will give you instructions on how to treat the cats - I know what it's like to get aggressive when petting the cats because they're so stinking cute, but you gotta try to control that.  The staff are very protective of the cats, as they should be.  There's plenty of items to buy from the Kittea Cafe - I would recommend that.  And lastly, the toilet in this cafe is high-tech...it might be worth the trip...weird, but useful.  

Stay fluffy, my friends.  Meow!
author: Lauren K.

description: Great experience! The cats were so clean and socialized. The cat wranglers were super nice and fun too!
author: Joey H.

description:
KitTEA Cafe was actually a great concept, but do your reading / research before you get there so you know what to expect.

KitTEA Cafe has two rooms. One is a cat play area behind a looking-glass. The cat play area has benches and tables where humans can get comfortable in the cat territory. :) In this room, you can eat, drink, and play with the cats. The other room is a café, located directly next to the cat play area so that you can watch the cat action but not get cat hair on you. In the café, they serve a few kinds of teas and coffees as well as waffles and sandwiches. There is also good wifi here.

I was surprised that as a cat woman, I opted to not go in the cat play area. Unfortunately, the cost was pretty high at $25 for 1 hour with the cats, and a reservation was required. Perhaps it is because I have cats of my own at home, I did not desire to pay so much to play with some cats, even though they were so cute and lovable. Having paid $70 to adopt a cat of my own, $25 seemed like a hefty price tag for an hour with some cats. But if you don't have cats of your own, this price may be worth it to you.

So, I had some good tea and a waffle and sat down with my laptop to do some work. It was, overall, a very calming environment. Cats don't like to be startled so the environment is quite quiet, even in the cafe area. It is also nice to look at the cats while seated in the cafe. Of course, I'd have loved to pet them, but I wasn't wiling to pay the price. I do appreciate that KitTEA gives back and finds homes for many cats who need them.

The food was good, 4/5, and the setting was also good, 4/5. Go online and think about how much time you are willing to pay for to be in the company of some well-mannered cats. It definitely looked like good cat therapy, but I could not get behind it at that price point.
author: Chelsea S.

description: I friggen love this plaaace! So much! I really really really do! I literally travel from Los Angeles to spend time with these cats, they are so cute, their little meows are perfect.
author: Miranda B.

description:
So this is a real thing, right? Color me surprised that there are about sixty cat cafés in Tokyo because this feels like such a giggly Harajuku thing. Two words: Hello Kitty. Besides, they all live in tubes over there or something not much bigger, so the idea of sipping tea and fondling a cat is most appealing to the workaholic and spaceaholic Japanese professional. Now San Francisco has one in Hayes Valley on the ground floor of a modern condo building. I came in on a Saturday at 3PM and found out they were fully booked until 8PM when they close. Hey, no whiskers off my nose since I'm allergic anyway. Did I mention it costs $25 for an hour of heavy petting?

It's five dollars less on weekdays, and they offer a Happy Meow'r (get it?) for $15 per hour on Thursdays 3-6PM. There are ten to fifteen cats, most less than a year old, who prance around indifferently in a large room with a long wooden bench, pillows, and all sorts of cat toys (photo: http://bit.ly/2nzjDC7). Ain't that precious? I could see them through the window quite easily, though the most entertaining part of the show are the humans who go to great lengths to cajole the cats into purring submission (photo: http://bit.ly/2nKIcwo). I was watching them through a large window on the tea house side where they serve paninis, waffles, soups and salads, and pastries.

Me? I went for the $9 pot of Sencha Tea (photo: http://bit.ly/2mOGcEf), one of eight teas they serve along with matcha, cold brews, and Four Barrel coffee. As the most popular tea in Japan, sencha was described on the chalkboard menu as "classic + grassy + clean". Grassy? They make it sound like mulch when it's refreshingly mellow for a green tea since the leaves are not pulverized into the tea itself. I had plenty to sip in front of the window as the feline shenanigans played out in front of me with adoring cat lovers in thrall. Most of the people, staff included, were easily amused by the kitties. I was wondering what skinny young people did for fun since they obviously don't eat. Now I know.

TEA - 3.5 stars...nice authentic pot of green tea
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...one-third tea house, two-thirds cat playground...you do the math
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...well, the tea ladies were nice
TOTAL - 3 stars...for feline aficionados only....meow
author: Ed U.

description: All my cat dreams came true here. As a cat owner and a lover of all animals, this place was AMAZING. My friend and I got here a bit early and we did eat after rather than during because we wanted to spend out time playing and taking pictures of the cats. All the cats were wonderful and they tell you how to pet them and pick them up. The employees were all amazing and fairly knowledgable about their cats and cats in general. After, we ate some beligium waffles before heading out in the cafe part. I got the salmon one and it was amazing. It was such a wonderful and exciting experience. I wish there was one in Boston - hint, hint.
author: Sam T.

description:
This was a really hard review for me to write. I have a love-hate feeling with this establishment. I absolutely love cats and I like waffles so combining the two would be a home run right? Not really. 

Let's talk about the food first. Our waffles were cooked to order and they were cooked very well. They separate the food side from the cat side that way things are clean. I really appreciated the level of concern they had over the cleanliness of my food and it showed because the food was delicious. 5 Stars for the food. 

Now on to the cat experience. If you love cats and would like to be in their company then don't get your hopes up too much. The cats here don't really like people. They didn't want to play or interact with people. They really just wanted to do their own cat thing. The only time the cats would get close is when you had food. Which I only got a pinch of cat food (like 7-10 little pebbles). I came here with my fiancé hoping to get some kitty action. BE WARNED. These cats are not here for you, but you get to see them. The cat handlers explained the process and gave us a brief explanation before releasing the cats.   

So why am I giving it three stars? I  base it off the value that I'm getting. If the entire experience costed me about 20 or $30 it would've been worth it and I would've given a five star but the experience costs more than that. I understand that this is probably the rate they have to charge to keep in business but I will not be coming back here again.
author: Jawid H.

description:
Came here for my birthday! The cats are all super cute and friendly! But most of them were sleeping :( I guess we came during nap time? I wouldn't have been able to interact with them if it wasn't for our cat wrangler bring out some treats! Then alllllllll the cats appeared! It was fun to feed them and see them awake haha. 

I would recommend going it's really nice atmosphere!
I would also maybe tell the cat wrangler to bring some treats if the kitties are asleep or hiding. 
Wasn't so much a fan of the complimentary teas, but you can order anything you want from the cafe! 

Overall a nice experience and a great stress reliever
author: Al H.

description:
I'm more of a dog person than a cat person.  However, I had a really great time here with my friends and it's safe to say that I would come back again.  

First of all, make sure you book a reservation online before coming.  It's $25 per hour on weekends and $20 per hour on weekdays.  At first, I thought the fee was kind of ridiculous, but it made me feel better that it comes with bottomless green teas.  Also, check in on Yelp and you can try another tea!  The teas were pretty good, but obviously my focus was more on the cats so I didn't really have too much time to sample all of them.    

Once your reservation starts, you take off your shoes (don't forget socks!), sanitize your hands, and off to kitty heaven!  My reservation was 2 pm so a lot of cats were taking naps.  However, there were still some who were awake and pretty willing to be held.  Usually cats straight up hiss at me, but these ones were overall pretty friendly.  The people working here were also really helpful and friendly.  I appreciated learning the cats' names and their history.  The hour went by way too fast.  

I left with a huge smile on my face.  Enough to say that it was worth every penny.
author: Shannon L.

description:
My dream is no longer a dream. I have finally gone to a cat cafe and I loved the experience of spending time with kitties that are spoiled as hell and loved. The complimentary green tea was also very good and very enjoyable with my experience.

Had great customer service, a wonderful selection of merchandise, and tempting snacks to enjoy if I had been hungry.
author: Samantha A.

description: My 12 year old niece and I loved our time with the kitties! Thank you!
author: Michelle W.

description:
I came here on a Saturday afternoon, and it was a pretty disappointing experience. I booked the 1 hour session for $25 for 2 people.

1) Way too many people per session, and not enough cats. My girlfriend and I could barely find room to sit on the bench. While the dude who worked there said there were 13 cats, there were only 4-5 in the main play area. The "cat wrangler" finally decided to give us treats to feed the cats 40 minutes into the hour, which drew out a few more kitties from their hidey holes, but we had already wasted a shit ton of time.

2) The cats are exhausted. This is the case with most "cat cafes." The cats are overstimulated and all they want to do at noon is sleep. Out of the 4-5 cats that were out and about, 2-3 of them were in little cage perches near the ceiling, so you can't even play with them if you wanted. You have to wait your turn and hope that the other guests are kind enough to not hog the cats. Otherwise you're sitting there twiddling your thumbs for 30 mins.

3) Overpriced food/drinks - I don't blame the establishment for this. This is how they make money. The food/drinks are overpriced nonetheless.

4) Strange fishbowl environment. The cafe consists of 2 sections. The cat play area, and the cafe. Clear glass separates the two and while you're playing with the cats, the guests in the cafe basically just stare at you. I found it pretty creepy, but maybe others won't.

Overall, Kit Tea was a disappointing experience, but at least my girlfriend got to pet some kitties, which made her feel better after a stressful week and time away from her cats back at home in the North East.

I would not recommend this place to anyone who does not live and breathe cat. Definitely do not go here in the afternoon!
author: Neivin M.

description: This place is sooooooo cute and relaxing. I would totally go here everyday if I could. We got to meet about 10 cats of all sizes and colors. The cats totally tried to ignore all the humans but over all it was nice watching them eat dinner. Tons of toys in the room to play with the cats and the tea that was served for the humans was yummy. :)
author: Kristia S.

description:
You've gotta be kitt'ing me. 

Beautiful cats, legit Japanese tea, all rolled up in one amazing experience? I am ALL in. Like, fur real.

KitTea is one of the first cat cafés outside of Japan and is a paw-some place to chill for cat lovers, tea enthusiasts, or even just window-side curious observers. Came here with a friend on a Saturday night and we LOVED it. You should definitely come in the evening at 7 pm, there is less of a crowd and the cats are super energetic and excitable because they get fed at 8 pm. Reservations are made online, and if you have a party of 8 or more you'll need to book yourself a private event. If you don't want to be amongst the kitties but would still like to watch, there's a room next door where you can order tea, coffee, food and get a good look at the cats just loungin' around. Their tea was also super delicious, I recommend adding the unlimited tea option to your visit because one cup will not be enough. My favorite was the Hojicha and the Genmaicha.

Oh and they are not adopting out any of the cats at the moment! I was told they have paw-sed their adoption services for the time being, and aren't sure when they'll have this option available again. Nevertheless, it's still a purr-fect place to hang around cats. Wish I was back there right meow.

(All puns, intended.)
author: Noimee L.

description: Having never been a cat cafe and loving both tea and cats I couldn't resist. You get unlimited refills of 4 interesting green teas with the cats tho they have a bigger tea and food menu as well. After a brief intro your in there sipping tea and snuggling with about a dozen cats in a small group for the hour. I also added on a bubnle waffle wrap filled with strawberries, goat cheese, sharp cheddar, and a fig drizzle which was light and tasty. Some cats are more playful then others but next time ill cover myself in cat nip and eat a tuna sandwich beforehand they cant resist.
author: Sean G.

description:
Love KitTea cafe! Their cats are super playful and friendly and the tea is actually very good! Highly recommend getting reservations early and trying their hojicha. While you can't adopt all the cats in there, they did have one available for adoption in the back. I love that they have a cat wrangler in the kitty room with you to give you backstories about the kitties, help you order tea/food, and teach you how to play with them!

Their gift shop swag is also hella cute. :)
author: Evonne L.

description: Amazing experience! Having tea while petting some cool kitties! Highly recommended for cat lovers! Friday BYOB board game event seems to be the most popular event here.
author: Koosha N.

description:
Like many San Franciscans, I love animals but can't have pets in my apartment. KitTea has my cat fix.

I came for the Wednesday night "Cats on Mats," in which a yoga instructor gives you a nice easy stretch while cats make themselves comfortable on the mat underneath you, or hop on your shoulders in the middle of Warrior pose, or try to eat your hair in Child pose. 10/10, best yoga class ever. 

If your home accepts fluffballs, all the cats are adoptable! If not, you can support KitTea by patronizing the cafe (they have genmaicha and other delicious green teas most cafes don't stock). If you love journaling, splurge on some adorable cat-themed stickers, stamps, and OH MY GOD THE WASHI TAPE. Just...so much cat stuff. So much.

I have a desperate need for furry animals in my life and KitTea scratches the itch. Thanks for existing. (I have no photos to share, because I was too busy petting cats and living in the moment and such.)
author: Aubrie J.

description: This place is completely fabulous.  A nice relaxing way to spend an hour (although I could have stayed for several hours).  The cats are sweet as can be, and the people that work with them are lovely as well.  This is a must for cat lovers!!!  I will definitely visit again if I find myself back in San Francisco.
author: Jennifer B.

description: I was looking for something unique and fun to do with my daughter for her birthday. She loves cats so I thought this would be purr-fect. I was right. She loved EVERYTHING about it. I felt that the cats were all loved and well taken care of. The Cafe is so clean and the staff was very friendly and made the experience great! Cats are special unique animals.  They have a mind of their own .  There's no guarantee that a cat will end up sitting on your lap purring but they will definitely keep you entertained for an hour.  I had a scone and French press coffee. Both were excellent. We will be returning.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This was so awesome I got to meet the kittenxlady from Instagram and Andrew I'm so happy that they put this event on that they came to San Francisco.
 You could do reservations on the internet paid $25 per person during the week for 1 hour to play with the kitties in the Kitty room they have happy hour on Thursday which is $15 today was a special event you get 30 minutes to play with the kitties you can have your Munchies in there with them, the rules are shoes off socks on sanitize your hands sanitize your hands if you're going to touch kittens from big cats.so you don't pass on any Kitty cooties don't bother them when they're sleeping above your head  their little safe place otherwise have a great time hide your purse bag backpack cuz the kitties will tear it open and get any kind of food if they smell anything. lol  
Then they have a little gift shop in the front as you walk in I ordered the simple Belgian waffle with Organic syrup little butter the only thing I was disappointed that it was room temperature wasn't hot, it's a little too pricey in here but what do you expect for something that has nice Ambience and kitties so you're supporting them and that's a good thing, but I only ate half cuz it was too big and they have a lot of teas they have coffee hot chocolate they had almond scones today. They have a bathroom inside where the tea area is in the cat area FYI when you go into the bathroom in the tea area the seat warms your butt took me by surprised when I sat down very clean in there. So if you like tea and you like to interact with cats here's two-for-one go to their web page Instagram Facebook Twitter check them out have a great time if you're following the kittenxlady you should definitely meet her and Andrew they are so awesome and she's will educate you or answer questions very friendly.
author: Lizzie G.

description: What an amazing experience! If you are a cat lover or animal person you will love this place! The workers are welcoming, friendly, and knowledgeable. The cats were chill and does their own thing from taking naps to playing around. Its interesting observing their behavior with one another. This place has therapeutic and relaxing ambiance. I enjoyed my experience here. I would highly recommend this place for cat lovers out there!
author: Alliver V.

description:
The cutest, most unique cat cafe I have ever visited!
So far I've only done yoga with cats as well as eat waffles with the cats. My absolute faves are Burger and Tippi. The waffles and tea go hand in hand. I also really appreciate the employees excellent customer service!
author: Phuck U.

description: I was excited to come here for months leading up to my trip. I love cats and tea but I was so disappointed. The girls were so incredibly rude I've never met anyone with such bad customer service and absolutely no people skills. I feel bad for those who travel just to come see the place. To say it's a let down is an understatement.
author: Reri H.

description:
I love it here! Make sure to check out their Happy Meowers and Caturdays! 

The cats are very sweet and adorable. The area is quite small but who cares!? The cats are lovely. The workers here are also kind and you can tell they love cats too. I would recommend going here with a group of friends or a friend/sibling. 

Overall, it's a positive place and I wish it was longer than a hour!
author: Angelina G.

description:
The cutest little establishment that brings back memories of Japan & Korea! Most cats are also up for adoption, so don't be afraid to fall in love!
The best advice I can give to those is to come during off hours (weekdays during HH). The biggest thing I had an issue with was that there were too many people in the kitty room at once. For about 10 cats there were about 10-12 other people in the room. As this would mean a cat per couple, some cats were actually sleeping or didn't want to be bothered. So I felt like we didn't get the full experience of being surrounded by cats as we lounged around.

While you wait for your time slot, they invite you into the tea lounge to enjoy 4 free unlimited tea flavors. You can watch the cats play while finishing the refreshments. The actual kitty room had plenty of beds, toys, and lounging areas. It was difficult to get the attention of the available cats, I wish they offered low calorie treats or catnip to use.
Overall it was a great experience and makes for cute IG photos
author: Jacqueline N.

description:
Upon arrival you are immediately told the game plan: order food and drinks, take shoes off, put adorable socks on, HAVE FUN WITH KITTIES!!! 

This was a very well put together cafe, and I especially appreciated the lengths they had taken for the health and safety of the kitties.
author: Mikaela B.

description:
KitTea Cat Cafe is a dream come true. It's exactly what it sounds like. Cats and tea, along with some baked goodies.

I came here first for a yoga + cats session, which is held in the evening on Wednesday. Purchase tickets in advance as they can only accommodate a certain number of participants. Your ticket also includes a hot tea of your choice, so come a little earlier to enjoy before the session. The yoga instructor was delightful and you practice in the room with the cats strolling around. One cat even jumped on someone's back! Overall highly entertaining and relaxing.

The second time I came in to do some work in the cafe portion, which there is a large glass window to peek inside the cat room. I found this enjoyable as I love people/cat watching as I typed away on my laptop. It's completely free to hangout in the cafe portion, which sometimes can get crowded when people come in before their session as it acts as the waiting room.

The hot teas are great. The ice cream waffle I got was rather sad. It came out with melted puddles of cream and it was a soggy sad mess. Maybe the other ones are better?

The cat room itself is rather small, like small bedroom. So you're awkwardly sitting in a room staring at each other. Also, their motto is now to keep resident cats, so most likely you will not see new ones next time (or have the ability to adopt). It's definitely a great start and I hope they can expand soon!
author: Minh N.

description:
Enjoyed our time on Monday at the KitTea Cat Cafe in San Fran. The handlers and front desk staff were friendly. The lunch was delicious.

My only concern is that during the hour we spent with the cats, when it came time for giving them treats, the cats were very aggressive and seemed to be starving for the kibble. Many would grab our arms and bit our hands to get at the kibble. 

I hope that the cats are not being under fed.

Karen
author: Karen W.

description:
My partner and I are from NYC where there are a few cat cafes, so we thought it would be nice to visit one while we were visiting San Fran. It was an odd experience.

Let me start by saying the staff is great. They were very nice and clearly care about the cats. 

It is a small space and they let in way too many people at a time. The room was packed.

It seems they have a problem with some intense repeat customers. There were three different people in the room with us who seemed a bit off, obsessive and possessive of the cats. We learned very quickly that they come in all the time and they don't really want the cats to go near anyone else. Anytime a cat came near us, one of these repeat customers scared them away. Of course this isn't the staffs fault - I wish they had a way to fix this.

Every hour, they give customers treats for the cats - each person gets a handful - this is a terrible idea when the cats are aggressive. I watched many people get scratched badly, the food was distributed very unevenly and it isn't a fun or cute experience like you would think. 

AND- the cats aren't even adoptable? Isn't that the point of a cat cafe - to find homes for shelter cats? These cats live there full time to be poked and prodded at by strangers.  

We both left feeling uncomfortable with the experience.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
This is hands down the coolest place I've ever been! To interact with the cats, you'll need a reservation ($25 per person and includes unlimited green tea). Otherwise, you can sit in the cafe area and watch the kitties through a large glass window. The tea and coffee are amazing, and the waffles look amazing! The staff are SO NICE. And obviously, the kitties are absolutely amazing and perfect in every single way. Apparently this was the first cat cafe that opened in the US. They offer yoga with cats every Wednesday evening, so I guess I will have to check that out the next time I'm here! 

P.S. I ordered the earl grey tea, and it was delicious
author: Anna H.

description:
KitTea is amazing! The cats all have their own personalities and are not afraid to run up to you and sit in your lap or jump on your shoulders. The employees are super sweet and will answer any questions. You also get unlimited green tea for your visit, even when you're in with the cats! Note: wear comfy clothes that you aren't afraid to get cat hair on and that you can get down on the ground in. 

It was hard to hold my squeals in, but you are surrounded by cat lovers so you will NOT be judged. 

$20 for 1 hour in the cat lounge. + unlimited hot green tea.
author: Mimi M.

description:
Where have you been all my life? I never knew that I had a soft spot for cats until today. When I went to visit the kittens at KitTea Cafe. I first heard of this when I got back from Japan and was super stoked to check it out since I didn't get to visit any of the animal cafes in Japan. I love that they rescue cats from the kill shelter and then put this together so that they can be adopted. My friend and I came on a Saturday afternoon, and it was packed! We got to the cafe at 12 so that we could eat beforehand, and I'm glad we did, because even though you can bring your food and drink into the play area, there is no way you're going to want to "waste" your time eating when you could be playing with kittens. 

You get unlimited green tea with your 1 hour visit, and you can actually switch between the 4 available types of teas. Awesome. We just went down the list, but never made it to #4. My friend got the heirloom tomato waffle and I got the grilled cheese sandwich. She enjoyed her waffle (the waffles smelled amazing) but I thought my sandwich was just ok. I wouldn't come here for the food, but it wasn't bad. 

When it came time to enter the play room, you have to take off your shoes and sanitize your hands, but then you pretty much have free roam of the place. It was so cute watching all the different cats - some were sleeping, 2 were cudding (omg I could not get enough of those two), some were super playful, some just did not want to be held. LOL. I was so in love and texted my husband that I want a cat. Eeee!!
author: Jennifer T.

description: Service is great. Food is good. Really pricey! We spent $200 today because it is $20 a person to reserve a space with the cats and then if you add food at $11 a waffle, it adds up quickly. With the $20, you get bottomless green tea but you have to pay extra for herbal tea. My children loved it but again, not something we will do much as it is expensive.  Great staff and clean establishment. I thought it would be disgusting eating with cats but they keep it really clean.
author: Nettie A.

description: Had a wonderful time here! The atmosphere was very calm and therapeutic. My friend and I had a 12pm reservation to play with the cats for an hour and was provided complimentary green tea. We also ordered a salad, scone, and coconut kitty paw cookie. The food was great, the kitties were adorable and soft, the staff was extremely nice, and the cafe was super clean. Overall, I would definitely recommend coming here for a really nice experience.
author: Sheiva Y.

description:
The staff was purrfect, the kitties were playful, the tea was pawsome.

We really enjoyed our time at Kittea and will be back anytime we visit the Bay Area
author: Kevin M.

description:
To be fair: I love cats.  I love tea.  Such a puuuuurfect combo (sorry for the cheesy joke) at KitTea Cafe!

I've been to a few cat cafes but this one stands out as one of my favorites.  I love how there is a cafe waiting room in case you arrive early / want to sit around after your one-hr time slot to just get a view of the glory of the cats.  Certain teas are free when you book an appointment- I got the genmaicha (green tea with roasted mochi rice); this one is on the stronger side but I love stronger tasting green tea.  Didn't try the waffles but another time I visited I had the matcha tea- so strong in flavor but not too bitter, this matcha is up there with other matcha teas I've tasted.

If you don't want to play with the cats but just watch them, you are welcome to just sit and order tea (you'll have to pay for it)- I've done work by the counter while sitting tea and watching cats and it surprisingly was a pleasant experience too.

Most of the cats were super friendly- there were a lot of times where they wouldn't react too much if someone picked them up while they were sleeping (I feel bad about doing this, but food for thought).  They are usually cooperative and will let you hold them for a bit of time until they squirm away.  

Staff were very engaging explaining each of the personalities of the cats, cat training / handling in general, or other random topics!  You can tell that they cared a lot for the cats in the cafe (and I've been to a few cat cafes where that was questionable).  

Tips:
- Bring socks!  You can buy at the shop too if you forget (though you don't have to wear it), but the floors can get cold so keep that in mind if your feet easily get cold
- Come at a non-busy hour- the staff noted that there was a birthday party a few hours ahead of our time slot and therefore some of the cats were sleeping / wanted some solitude.  I suspect that the cats would be more awake if you came when there wasn't any big event like this, so might help to call ahead of time if you are really looking to playing with cats
- These are cats- they have their own personalities and own little lives and therefore might not be as cooperative as you want them to.  Most of the cats are pretty mellow and will allow you to pick them up, but don't hope to be able to pick up and coddle with every single one.

If you like cats and just want an hour (or more) to get your endorphins going, I'd suggest coming here.  After all, isn't it a fact that having more animals in your life makes you a happier person?
author: Audrey H.

description: Definitely MAKE A RESERVATION ONLINE if you want an hour in the lounge with the cats. They book up very quickly! I attempted to do a walk-in at 2:30 pm on a Thursday and they were fully booked until 6 pm. But I was able to enjoy the cafe (free of charge) and sat at the bar which looks into the cat lounge. Really nice little menu with teas and nibbles. They offer yoga, movie nights, and Saturday morning cartoons with the cats (sign-up separately online). Definitely love the decor and all of the cat inspired gifts they sell.
author: Sarah N.

description:
While visiting San Fran, I wanted to take the opportunity to check out a cat cafe -- so trendy, right? 

Maybe my imagined standards were too high or just too different from what we got at KitTea. I thought it would be more of a relaxed sort of "bookstore with cats" environment. I imagined languid but friendly cats and a private table with a mug of something warm and other humans a good 10-15 feet away. I thought the cats would just be cats and the humans would be chill, willing to give pets and cuddles as cats wished to accept them, laps welcoming to not insisting. 

Humans are the worst. I didn't expect for there to be so many other humans sharing my KitTea cat time in such a relatively small space -- probably 12 or so, a ratio of about one person to one cat. I didn't expect these people to be so "KITTY!!!!" I didn't expect people to be so insistent on playing and petting to the point they were almost grabby-handed toddlers. 

Perhaps the cats are used to this behavior. They seemed entirely unconcerned and rather disinterested in affection -- not the aloofness we love about cats but rather a sort of overstimulation such that the human visitors weren't anything special. There was no bonding. Their interest was in food. 

As for food, there's little by way of "cafe." There are some munchies and tea and coffee, but don't expect to relax away with finger sandwiches, cream brûlée and Whiskers by your side. 

All these things said, the tiny gift selection is cute and well done. Staff members are kind. The cats appear well cared for. Everything is neat and tidy. If you could book out the space entirely for two hours with 8 or fewer of your good, chill friends, and watch a movie or work a puzzle or do yoga, you'd totally enjoy it. It would be swell to see the cats rotated throughout the day for play time/quiet time. 

There's so much potential here! Here's hoping to a long future.
author: Sarah K.

description:
An animal lovers delight! My two favorite things in the world, cats and tea. It's located in a little cafe that feels like heaven. The cats all have different personalities so there is a cat for everyone. The tea and sandwiches are delicious, and they even have gluten free bread for those with a sensitivity. They even have a wide variety of cat lady gift items and items for your cat or cats. They also have a Kit Tea monthly gift box that is a must have for any cat lover.

This will be a favorite stop for me on each of my trips to San Francisco from now on.
author: La Wanda S.

description:
I love KitTea! What else could be better than cats in a cafe?? 

But in all seriousness, this is really a great place. The staff are very friendly, knowledgeable, and obvious care about the cats and the patrons. 

The cafe section offers plenty of seating, space to use your laptop, a variety of tea and baked goods, and a great view of the cat room. 

I've gone to Happy Meowr and the hour-long Cat Visits. Both were so fun. The first time I went, one of the cats fell asleep in my lap for the whole hour and I didn't want to leave. There's usually about 10 cats walking around, sleeping, playing etc. It's a very peaceful environment for both the cats and the humans and I'd go back every week if I could.

Plus they have super cute merch.
author: Cassandra B.

description:
I've never been to a cat cafe (concept taken from Japan), however you pay $25/person to go play with the cats. If there's already a large group there, you won't really have a chance to play with the cats because there aren't enough cats!

Would not recommend. The people there servicing the place was really nice though!
author: Ellen C.

description: This place was adorable.  The cats are super friendly and the cat lounge has very cute decor.  It smelled much better than I thought a room with 20 cats would smell. They have complimentary green tea, which was good. My son ordered a milkshake and loved it. We will for sure be coming back.
author: Christina L.

description:
I am an animal person, despite only having a dog. However, I make up for this by volunteering at the SF Zoo. Regardless of your opinions about zoos, I know how to handle animals, but I also understand the feelings of the caretakers behind-the-scenes.

The cats were chill, but definitely not the most playful. It does suck that I paid $20 for literally just petting cats for an hour, but I get respecting the animal and I was petting cats for an hour. This is something most patrons of, for lack of a less negative word, animal entertainment places feel upset about. The humans are not able to make sure an animal reciprocates the love and attention you are giving it, so please do not blame the business, caretakers, or cats.  

I wonder if they rotate the cats. The cats seemed to come and go as they please to the back and a few stayed there. To echo a previous review, I did witness some fellow customers not understanding the cats are not just for their entertainment. I was also under the assumption that it would be a " 'bookstore with cats.' " I wish supervision was better enforced like, "Hey, sorry, but Steve (one of the cat's names) isn't feeling it right now. Would you like to give your attention to another one of our cats?" Besides that, the cats looked well cared for. 

Speaking of the people, the guy was nice.

The place was cramped which I did not like. I hope that in the future, they can acquire a bigger facility, which means more cats! Hopefully, the same number of people admitted each session with maybe 1-2 additional spaces. 

However, after this experience, I am seriously considering getting a cat in addition to a dog when I live not at home. A cat is like a child you can depend on to be independent and you don't have to spend a lot of time and energy and attention on them, not that I mind devoting that to dogs, but there's a sense of relief with that. 

Oh! Before I forget, food! The food was okay. I wasn't a big fan of their tea selection. Nothing wrong with it, but I am the girl who doesn't like sushi, green tea, or seaweed which are all common likes amongst people. Their grilled cheese was pretty tasty. I loved the gooeyness. Their calico Belgian waffle was okay. Nothing special, but not terrible. 

TLDR:
- People can be buttheads. Please be understanding. 
- Cramped. 
- I wish they could be more transparent. They are open to questions, I just felt they should've been obvious/answered. 
- The food was okay. 
- They have one of those Japanese heated toilet seats.
- Is it worth $20 or $25? Eeehhh. It's for a good cause and it comes with bottomless tea and cats to pet/admire.
author: Millissa T.

description: Very nice venue. Well maintained. They have 14-16 cats that permanently live there and rotate kittens to adopt. We were all given treats to get the cats used to us and there were lots of toys and seating to play. It was a. Fun lunch hour!
author: Stephanie W.

description: Brought my mom here for her birthday, and she absolutely LOVED playing with the cats (she's a total cat person). The people running the cafe were nice enough ti provide tea refills throughout the entire hour we were there. However, I still cringe thinking about how much I had to pay to book a reservation for us...
