I was VERY EXCITED to check this place out, as I'd been to Cat Town in Oakland and had a fantastic experience and wanted to see what its competitor offered.

OVERALL, I had a great experience. Yes, prices are high, but so is everything in San Francisco, so if you're here from out of town just know their prices are fair, especially for handmade merchandise. The tea & waffle I ordered were great! The cold brew, not so much. It was poorly filtered & tasted sandy and I don't think they dilute it, it was darker than space and so strong my hands were shaking after half a cup! 

Cats are about as you'd expect, they're cats. However, the experience with these cats was different from my experience at Cat Town - These cats were JUNKIES for treats and seemed to be interested in nothing else. They quickly flocked to customers who had purchased treats before entering. It was cute that they'd jump up on you and eat out of your hands and lick your fingers, but none of them were receptive to petting except one or two who were asleep. Even a little ear skritch! Cats are like that but this felt like being scammed by a bunch of four-legged fuzzballs who were only in it for the tuna. Treats are a good way to get a cat's attention but it made me a little sad that that was all they seemed to care about. :( They also could use a better selection of toys, the cats didn't seem too interested in anything that didn't move and most of the toys were stuffed mice and the like. 

In any case, I will probably go back but I will have lower hopes for kitty interactions next time. Get treats before you go in if you want to be the Kitty King!
author: Sally D.

description: KitTea was wonderful. I've heard of some sketchy cat cafes before, but this was not the case as the cats were treated so well. It was clean, friendly, relaxing, the food and tea was great, and they had cute things to buy in their gift shop. I'll definitely go back!
author: Sarah S.

description:
We made some reservations to pop by on Sunday at 4PM for an hour of cat and tea time mid-way through our 1-day SF trip. It was a perfect idea and probably the highlight of our day. After a long morning of traveling through Alcatraz, Pier 39, Chinatown, etc., this place was a godsend. We finally had a chance to regroup and charge our phones up somewhere quiet and homey -- with cats! All the residents were sleeping but, like, how can anyone complain about that?! Cats sleep like 19 hours a day lol. As a cat owner, I wasn't flustered at all, but a few of the other guests seemed to feel a little irritated that these poor kitties wouldn't hop up and play on command. The complimentary teas were great, but I wish they'd just bring out some pots right away because I felt awkward bugging the cat wrangler every 5 minutes for another cup. 

The Cat wrangler was awesome and you could tell he loves his job and each of the cats. :) He brought out a sleepy one-eyed kitty who was SO precious! It was great to say hi to all the residents and give 'em a little love. I loved this place and will definitely recommend it to friends and family as a nice way to catch your breath in SF.
author: Cortney C.

description: This has to be one of the cutest trends to happen ever. It's an adorable cafe with a really cozy tea shop right next to the cat lounge. The bottomless tea came with the $25/person reservation and the cats were really cute, but it's still on the pricey side of kitty experiences. The cats have definitely been more socialized and possibly have spent too much time being petted to be super excited to see you, but when you get past that, it was still a pretty therapeutic experience if you normally don't have pets. The service was great nevertheless and tea was not bad. I certainly can't afford to come here all the time, but I'm glad I could experience it at least once!
author: Cindy N.

description:
A lot of planning and care went into the making of KitTea. You can tell. It's a small space, but they're able to make it manageable. The tea and food menu is well thought out and gourmet. It's a great concept, obviously. Even if you aren't there for a cat room appointment, there's plenty to eat and drink and see the cats through the window.

This paragraph is really more suggestions for the staff, not a reflection of recommending spending your money to go. If you like tea, food and cats, then this is the place to go. There's just a couple of things I think they might want to adjust. First, there should be a few more cats. That's an easy fix. Also, there are ways to curate a cat selection to find cats that are more calm and personable. Cat adoption places, for example, are able to find cats that are particularly good with other cats. Or good with children. Lap cats, etc. The cats here are sweet, but they are a little hyper. I mean, look, they're cats, I get it, they're not easy to coral. They do what they want. But, you know, ideally. Also, the employee is a nice enough person, but I don't think they need to be hyping up the cats so much, and talking so much and so loudly, and sharing so much other stuff on their phone. Just let the guests experience the room, and maybe blend into the background a little. Be seen, not heard. Take orders when asked, which is a great feature, by the way.

I do recommend KitTea, despite some of the suggestions above. So don't let that dissuade you. It's really more suggestions to the owners in general to help them make the place even better. So, in short, it's a solid, interesting experience. Certainly unique and worth the price for the different type of experience and the food and tea. So, again, if you like cats, tea, waffles, and more, KitTea is recommended, highly.
author: Rob F.

description:
The décor here is absolutely adorable! Wooden shelving lines the walls for the cats to run along. It's very well-lit and modern but still cozy. There's a wide variety of cat-themed books and knick knacks to browse through while you're checking in or waiting, as well. KitTea has a small café adjacent to their cat room where you can hang out and watch some playful and dozing kitties through a large window, as well as grab a bite and some great tea, without a reservation. Small succulents in hammered copper pots rest on each table. 

Their green teas are complimentary with your reservation in the cat room, and their genmaicha was delightful. It was earthy and deep but not overly grassy like some green teas. Food can be eaten in the cat room as well as the café, you just have to carry it in. I can't comment on the taste of the food, since I wasn't hungry at the time. Someone next to me ordered one of their waffles, and it looked delicious, if you can eat it. They did have a vegan salad on their menu that sounded surprisingly filling.

I love the fact that all of the cats are up for adoption, so your visit helps further socialize them. There's also another room attached to the kitty room with a cat door where the cats can go if they get overwhelmed. It seems like a wonderful place for the kitties to be while they wait to find their forever homes/human(s). KitTea also offers a loyalty card that earns you a free visit once you fill it. Will definitely be returning :)
author: Zim M.

description: The cats were super cute, and the hour we spent there flew by fast. I'm planning to bring my other family and friends here because I know they would love it! Really enjoyed my time and can't wait to come back.
author: Josephine B.

description:
Wonderful staff, great tea and adorable kitties! The partnership with an adoption agency is another huge plus! They also have a lot of great cat merchandise from independent artists. 

My only criticism would be that I don't drink caffeine and the only tea offered was green tea. I had to pay extra for a decaf tea. That being said, it was all worth it!
author: Sabrina B.

description: Cats are boring, but the experience is worthwhile and the employees are amazing and deeply care about what they do and the kitty cats.
author: Julie R.

description:
My 9 year old son asked to write a Yelp review of Kit Tea, so here it is, guest review by B.C.:
"First of all I had a great time!  Everyone was nice and if you wanted something like more tea or food, they would be happy to help.  The food and drinks were delicious.  I had a waffle with Nutella and berries and a hot chocolate, my mom had a waffle with smoked salmon and goat cheese and tea.  I got four tasty marshmallows in my hot chocolate!
When we went into the "cat lounge" all there was were cats.  The cats were VERY social and would just jump right on my lap.  Overall it was a ten out of ten!  (Five stars.)"
author: Michelle K.

description: This was my third time at KitTea and it never disappoints. When all the kitties were a little too sleepy they brought out some food for us to give them, which was tons of fun and really livened things up!
author: Vicki Y.

description:
Cool concept. Finally, SF now has its first and only cat cafe to satisfy people's sudden urge to play with kittens and to test whether they are ready to adopt.

While it was fun coming in for a full hour, I was pretty disappointed with the cat to human ratio in the room. I came in late in the afternoon and majority of the cats appeared to be exhausted. Most were sleeping and absolutely did not want to be bothered. I feel as though coming here, I spent most of my time sitting around waiting for the next available cat or chasing after them, since the number of cats wasn't proportionate to the group.

Also, I find the rate of $25 for per hour with cats a bit overpriced so I probably won't be back.

On another note, the staff here and the bottomless tea was okay, the bathroom (and facility in general) is very clean and the decor of the cafe is modern.

Though they accepted drop ins when we were there, I suggest that you make a reservation in advance to ensure availability.
author: Jasmin H.

description: Wonderful cats and wonderful service.  A nice cozy way to spend a weekday.  Have been to KitTea a few times now and they never dissapoint.  The cats are very socialble and the food and tea is delish.  A Purrrrrrect score for KitTea!!
author: Sarah L.

description: Clean, chic and modern cafe. Tea was delightful. Cats were friendly and playful. Staff was polite and helpful. Drinking tea, eating a snack, and (very quietly and calmly) hanging out with well socialized cats is fun.
author: Cyrus C.

description: The visit was very sweet.  As soon as I arrived a mid-aged cat came and sat on my lap. The cats are very active first thing in the morning, so I would suggest you go early.  Most of the kittens and the older cats were ready for a nap by the time we left at 11:00 a.m.  Everything is  clean, and the cats are all very healthy.  It's too expensive for a return visit, but we enjoyed it as a special treat.
author: Kittycat J.

description:
Came here on a sunday @6pm.
Parking was rather difficult to find, had to circle around many times as they don't have dedicated parking or a parking garage nearby.

They had around 8 cats and 2 were sitting there drowsily and the rest were asleep. Since this place is by appointment, there were around 8 people in the same room.

The place is nice, the tea is good. However I would recommend for people to schedule an earlier time, otherwise all the cats are tired out and you cant play with them.
author: Alan A.

description:
I had no idea until recently that there was actually a cat cafe in San Francisco. The place is kept very clean (especially the cat room itself), and the best way to see the cats is to book a reservation in advance on their website, as space is limited and only a small number of people per time slot are allowed at a time.

$20-25 for an hour with the cats is asking quite a bit, but considering what you also get, I suppose it's worth it in the end. Complementary tea is included with your reservation. There are also other food and tea items for sale, which I thought was too expensive. Also, if you order any tea or food, the staff won't be able to serve it to you directly and this is in order to comply with food safety regulations. You are allowed to step right outside the cat room and then bring the tea and food from the cafe in with you.

Practically all of these cats are up for adoption through Wonder Cat Rescue; no same-day adoptions are available. These same cats must get a lot of human attention and petting each day. Even if some of the cats are sleeping, you can still pet them. Overall, something I'd recommend if you really love cats (and aren't able to have one of your own at home).
author: Paul N.

description:
The cats here are a solid 5, the tea and service a four.
This was our first experience at a Japanese inspired cat cafe, and overall it was an amazing time! 
On arrival and check in, the cafe seemed a little disorganized and the staff a little less than excited to greet us. We had made a reservation ahead of our visit (needed) which included unlimited green tea and a visit with some amazing cats for one hour. 
They do offer four varieties of green tea to choose from which is nice! The cafe also offers some sweet offerings like waffles, but we discovered it's smart to order those ahead when reserving if you want to partake. 
While enjoying our tea in the cafe we were able to enjoy watching the group ahead of us play with the cats through the large window between the cat lounge and tea lounge. 
Once our designated time came it was all cats! The hour went by in a flash. Our cat wrangler (I've forgotten his name, we'll call him "G") was amazing! Energetic, informative and engaging, he introduced us to the cats (there were six on our day) and made sure we were had everything we needed to have a great time. 
This cafe is doing great work for animals! They have found forever homes for over 160 cats to date! G let us know that they are very careful with adoptions and take time to make a right match. There is no meeting a cat on day one and taking it home that very day. Adoption is a process here. 
Whether looking to adopt, or just want a fun and unique new experience when visiting SF, I think everyone should visit the Kit Tea cafe!

PRO TIPS: 
Wear comfy shoes that can easily come off (socks only in the cat lounge)
Make a reservation 
If you want to eat, order ahead while reserving
author: Scott M.

description:
Who on earth thought of a concept like this? I think it was someone in Japan, or so I've heard. I admit, it's fantastic, but it's kind of unusual. In a nutshell, you make an appointment to pay to play with kittens and drink tea, hence the name, KitTea.

My friend and I had just finished lunch and I had a sudden urge to play with kittens. Damage control (in case my cat reads this): I house one of the best cats in the world, Wilson "Danger" the Cat, a full-grown Snowshoe with the best personality and cutest face, who I love dearly, and who smothers me with affection, climbs on my shoulders, and wants little more than to cuddle with me, my roommates, and anyone who comes over (he's a lover). But still, it's sometimes fun to have baby cats to hang around with. 

So upon my saying that kittens are adorable and I want to rub their little kitty tummies on my face, my pal remarks that there's a spot in Hayes Valley that can make my dreams of kitten playtime come true! So we head over, check in, choose our teas, and are let into the clean, Ikea-esque room with full windows looking out onto the street so passersby can get a glimpse of what they're missing out on. There were 15 kittens in the room, yes folks, real, baby kittens, some bigger than others, but all were still in the category of "kitten", mostly sleeping, playing with toys, lounging in the sun, walking on a giant cat wheel (like a hamster wheel for cats), and doing general kitten things.

One of the people who works there stayed with us in the room the whole time like a mediator which I thought was kind of weird, but then I thought they probably have to sit there to ensure that crazy people don't steal these adorable little fur balls who would fit just perfectly into my purse. Wait what? I kid, I kid. Actually KitTea is like a really expensive SPCA where folks can go have kitty time and decide if they're ready to adopt a little furry friend. If you're at that point, just do it. Cats are awesome pets and I hope you get one with as great a personality as my young friend Wilson who is currently rolled on his back with his soft underbelly being warmed by my laptop. Kitty love never grows old.
author: Crystal C.

description: Positive experience all around.  Very well run, helpful staff, lovely cats and good tea.  A unique and fun time for the whole family.
author: Susan B.

description: What a great place to spend time with a friend getting to know each kitty cat in that cats own space and in their time. The book provided detailing each cat was a gem. Written to be informational and humorous, really helped to learn about them individually. Burger and Steve definite favs. KitTea loves!
author: Donna F.

description:
Nice little hole in the wall KitTea café. There were about 13 cats at the time being but some of them were sleeping I think so we ended up playing with only 8-10 I'd say. We went for Friday movie night so they closed down the store for the movie. Definitely reserve online if you wanna come in to enjoy these crazy cats. I'm gonna be honest and say although the movie was playing, I was so distracted by the kitties that I didn't even bother watching the movie lol you can play with them, pet them, chase them down, and just be a total weirdo with them.

The only thing bad I have to say about this place is the chai tea...extremely strong and will knock you out after about 3 cups or so...I was getting woozy and was about to fall asleep lol oh and another bad thing is this place is very expensive during movie nights or any type of activity nights...our reservation for 2 during movie night came out to be $100 with an order of tea and it was for 2 hours. So think about it if you want to go here. Also, if you love the kitties a lot after playing with them then feel free to adopt them as well! Would I recommend this place? Probably if you have the money for it.
author: Rose C.

description:
Great idea, but it doesn't work well here. For starters, the tea and food seem like an afterthought. Even the people who ordered them didn't seem into it, which idk if that was bc it wasn't good, or because they were just bored. 

The boredom comes from the lack of cat activity. Most of the cats were asleep, and the ones that were awake didn't want to be touched at all! They weren't friendly, and even tried to bite people who just wanted to pet them. I got a few of the cats to play, but handed off the toy to a little girl who was there, as it was the only thing they seemed interested in for the time being. After that I just sat around for the remaining time, and no other cats wanted anything to do with us. 

The room was WAY too small for 8 people. Everyone had to stay to one corner to avoid walking over, or bumping into each other. There was one snuggle cat, but two girls kept it to themselves the whole time. It was the only one that allowed itself to be held. 

I don't blame the cats, especially if it's a matter of over stimulation, or worn out cats, that's fine, but that's the owners responsibility to space out visits so the cats aren't feeling smothered, and humans can actually get there monies worth, and not just sit in a room with 8 other people staring a sleeping cats. 

Also, the no cat option is awkward because people just sit outside the window and stare at you staring at cats. It made me uncomfortable. 

The only positive was the Japanese toilet in the restroom.
author: Dean J.

description: A friend took me here for my birthday because I love cats! It was a thoughtful gift. To get access to the cat lounge cost $20 per person, which is the weekday rate. I gather it is $25 on weekends and $15 at "Happy Meower." You get all-you-can-drink green tea with that, or pay for additional food / drinks. We had a waffle sundae. It was fun and a good size for two. Cat lounge: you have to take off your shoes and Purell your hands before entering. If you've ordered food or tea it is brought to just outside the lounge and you can step out for a sec to bring it in. We were there around Friday at 6pm. There were 10-12 guests with us in the lounge for that hour, and about 12-14 cats. My one complaint would be this ratio; if you know cats, you know that they don't want to play all the time, so it kinda got competitive among the people who wanted to play with the cats who were in a playful mood. A girl stole the cat I was patting by luring it away with a toy!!! THE NERVE!!! This gave me a sad until Chloe, our cat handler, introduced me to Ginny, a beautiful tabby who loves shoulders and Ioves being up high. Well I am six foot three so she loved sitting on my shoulders while I walked around. I wore her like a dead mink stole until I finally walked by an even higher shelf and she got off to groom for awhile. We were there during feeding, and it was a fun, ridiculous frenzy. I like that Chloe asked the whole group if we were ok with her feeding them now, because the cats basically ignored us for 15 minutes when Chloe prepared and served dinner. But that was OK, the feeding frenzy was a blast to watch. Strong recommend but keep your expectations in check by reading the FAQ on their website which is well written. I didn't do this because it was a surprise present, and a great one, indeed. Pro-tip: This is a good place for a first date, btw. There were at least two in progress while we were there. Pro-tip: there's a back room off the lounge (with a sink, storage, laundry) where some of the cats go to chill; you can go back there and find some kitties to pet that are away from the crowd, and it's super chill back there.
author: Dave M.

description: This place is adorable! Staff is super friendly and the food was good. The potato leek soup is delicious. Of course, the main attraction of the place is all the kitties, so cute. I'll have to take an allergy tab before my next visit so I can go in.
author: Raphael C.

description: Awesome in every way! Food super creative & delicious, staff nice, dedicated, & helpful, cat behavior specialist a howl, kitties ridiculously cute... a must-see!
author: Sherrill G.

description: Amazing!! The cats are adorable and the tea is delicious!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Innovative, cute, and with potential! My sister reserved an hour for us yesterday (Th 12/21 5-6pm). I was excited because I loved cats and the idea of a cat cafe. We waited in the cafe before our assigned time and drank tea. Then 10 people plus the cat wrangler/caretaker fit into a 9 feet x 12 feet room with 11 cats. Half of the cats stayed in the room and the other half roamed to the small adjacent back room, where trash bins, washer, dryer, cleaning supplies were. The cats were adorable and loving. The caretaker was knowledgeable and helpful in every way. The rooms were intoxicated with air fresheners. That prevented me from enjoying the services. Here are my humble suggestions:
-Refrain from the use of air fresheners because of allergies and health implications. If the litter boxes smell then clean them hourly. If the trash smells than put them somewhere else.
-Charge more, maybe $30-50/hour and have less customers. The 9ftx12ft room should not contain 11 people, maybe 6 for the best relaxation and enjoyment.
-Advertise to a wider market such as the retired, widows, housewives, bourgeoisie, LGBT. The customers I saw last night were consistently young people between 18-28 years old, in school or just settled in the city with a job. Except one single lady in her 40s. 
-Offer 2 organic teas, one herbal and one caffeinated, as part of the hourly packages. 4 types of unlimited green teas were offered with our package. Some people would not drink green tea in the winter due to the cooling effects. Some may not care for the caffeine. I would prefer one organic herbal tea such as rooibos and one caffeinated tea such as chai (seasonally appropriate and less tea to make available in mass volumes). 
-Exceptionally clean and air-fresh restroom and cafe. Keep up the good work.
-Young, helpful, energetic, good-looking staff. Keep up the good work. Maybe hire a male staff to boost your customer number and diversify on the long run.
All in all, I love the idea and believe they will succeed. I hope they would not use air fresheners and put so many people in the room, which were suboptimal physically and mentally for both humans and feline. I'm happy to pay $30-50 per hour. I would like to pay more to support them and for the good services. I would be happy to book the whole hour once a week or once a month for hubby and myself, if there are no air fresheners or smell of trash or kitty litter. Keep in mind my sister book the time because it was the cheapest, and I went along with her. At other times, there may be many less customers.
author: G D.

description: Love, love, loved it!! Having a purring cat on your lap soothes the soul.  I visited with my son and mother in law and all three generations were pleased as punch.
author: Chris A.

description: Despite the cats being a little on the anti-social side, I had the best time at KitTea. The tea tastes good and the cat playroom is comfy and cute. I suggest buying one of the food packets to be swarmed with all the love the cats can offer. They also offer fun events like movie nights and yoga with the cats. I have not gone to those yet but I plan on it.
author: Oceana M.

description: Awesome place to visit, they take such great care of all the cute kitties here, and the food is delicious!
author: Jesse R.

description: what a great concept to have tea with the kitties.  They're all taken great care of.  I recommend this very much.  We walked there, it's close from Union square.
author: Cindy M.

description:
At first listen, the concept seems like a pitch for a social experiment: "Let's put a group of human strangers in a room with cat strangers for an hour and see what happens!" There's a glass window separating participants from non-participants, who sip soothing tea while making remarks on the affability of the animals in the other room.

But once you remove your shoes and pad into the feline haven, you'll start to understand why a place like this exists. Some cats want to meet you, some cats are having introverted days and can't wait to get back to their latest Netflix binge. The extroverts approach, you bestow some scratches on them, and maybe you get a head butt in return. If you're lucky, your new friend will snooze on your lap.

San Francisco's veins throb with overstimulation: put these in your ears, eat this, take a picture of that, listen to this, watch this, wear this on your face, try this drug, let's go for venti coffees at 6pm.

Like all cats, the ones at KitTea owe you nothing. But you owe it to yourself to try KitTea. It's unusual, unpredictable, and uniquely relaxing.
author: Alek S.

description:
Come for the cats, not the food. 

My first ever experience at a cat cafe:

I reserved a spot for me and my friend a couple days in advance online with scone service--quick and smooth.

On the day of, we walked inside and were immediately asked if we had a reservation (I thought it was quite rude if I say so myself). After they confirmed our reservation, we were asked to head to the food room to get our scones. We sat there for a couple minutes and had tea while waiting for the cat room to be cleared (of humans lol). Scones were okay..definitely not worth the $6+ each though. At 3:00 exactly everybody headed into the cat room (there were about 7 other people). One of the staff told us some basic guidelines and the rest was play time. 

Most of the cats were asleep but it still was really enjoyable. Something about being in a room  with a bunch of kittens just feels very cuddly. Time passes by fast, you have been warned.
author: Anna H.

description:
The cats are cute but the place smells terrible. We ordered food and it was a terrible call. It is such a strong smell that there's no way you'll want to eat. 

I would consider the $25 fee to pet cats for an hour to be a donation to a reasonably good cause. If you think about it as an entrance fee, you may be sadly disappointed.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Great experience, amazing staff, yummy tea and best of all the sweet, coolest and best-treated cats in town. Get your cat and tea fix! Such a wonderful experience.
author: Brian K.

description: I love cats and love this catplace! Green tea was very delicious :)
author: Nika F.

description: Very relaxing! If you need a dose of animal therapy, this is definitely the place to go!
author: Betsy M.

description: The play room smelled of cat pee but it was very clean and lots of toys to play with the cats.  I wouldn't want to eat or drink in there though.
author: Lori G.

description: Exactly what it sounds like. Hang out with rescue cats and drink good tea. The staff is great. Definitely a must if you're a cat person.
author: Jesse A.

description: This place is purrfect for cat lovers! I came here during my finals week of college and the cats were able to relieve my stress! The facility is also clean and I like how you can see the cats from outside of the cafe! It was really hard to say goodbye to the cats but i'll be seeing them soon! Maybe i'll see some new faces too!
author: Polly Q.

description: This was such an amazing place for animal lovers ! Great team and great business !! Can't wait to go again and play with all these cuties
author: Erika B.

description: Fantastic experience! So fun ! Highly recommend! Took my daughter before she goes off to college! Great energy! What's not to love about cat therapy!
author: Kathi K.

description: We made a special trip to SF just to go to the KitTea Cafe and it didn't disappoint. The staff was friendly and helpful, it was a very clean and nice environment and the cats were hilarious.  We'll definitely be back!
author: Jennifer S.

description: We had a wonderful time! The kitties were affectionate, the staff was delightful, and the tea was delicious. Next time we will reserve 2 hours!
author: Shahri M.

description:
I'm glad I finally got the chance to check this place out, it's super cute! I went with my boyfriend on a Thursday afternoon during happy hour, and we loved meeting all the kitties. Most all of them were sleeping or relaxing except for a rambunctious kitten they had named Coco Puff, but they pretty much all seemed open to being pet while they were snoozing. The staff was all really nice and very helpful, and the chai tea was one of the best I've ever had! Like other reviews said, the cat room was super clean and you can tell they work really hard to hold the place to a high standard of cleanliness.

Even if you're not on the lookout for a forever pet, it's a really cute pIace to visit if you just enjoy being surrounded by a bunch of adorable cats. I'll for sure come back next time I'm in the area-- I only wish I were able to adopt a kitty right now, when I'm in the market for one this is a great place to look!
author: Kylie S.

description: The Kit Tea Cafe is a great experience. We arrived early to our reservation and got started early on the complimentary green tea selections. The staff was very welcoming and knowledgeable about the cats and general feline behaviors. Our cat wrangler was very accommodating and friendly. Our only advice for future visitors would be to come earlier in the day when the cats were less stimulated. The resident cats seemed sleepy and over stimulated by our 2:00 appointment. Our cat wrangler even gave us handfuls of dry food to entice the cats to interact with us and excite them. Overall I would visit again and loved meeting the "celebrity cats" that we have grown to love through Instagram. Shout out to Aunt Gail!
author: Kristi M.

description: A Cat-Holic can't live without cats! I'm 6 weeks away from home in San Francisco. This place is my cat-home this 6 weeks. This is the best cat café in SF.The staff there are so nice! Cute cats!   I love the milktea and Matcha!
author: Yang H.

description:
* Scheduling: I reserved a spot for 6pm on Monday at KitTea about a month in advance. I got a call the Saturday before that there had been a glitch in their calendar, and they're only open until 4 on Mondays. I didn't trust I'd be able to get from the airport to KitTea by then, and so I opted for noon on Wednesday.

* Price: It is expensive ($20/hr with drink). But it's my understanding that everything in SF is more expensive, so I wasn't shocked. And of course, if you get the tea they offer endless refills.

* Place: The building is small but clean. There's 3 separate rooms -- check-in with merchandise, the café, and then the cat room. It seemed off the main road to this visitor, but I walked from my hotel and didn't drive so I have no idea about parking. I didn't much care for the.... I'm not sure, modern incense burner? in the cat room. I assume it was to mask the cat smell, but it made my eyes water.

* People: Everyone was pleasant enough, though the two out front weren't too chatty/friendly. The cat room girl was pleasant and prompt about getting everyone's orders.

*Food/Beverage: I didn't eat anything, but my hot chocolate was pretty good, though it had a vaguely burnt aftertaste

* Cats: They were so friendly and cute, and I like that KitTea doesn't forbid you to pick them up. I ended up playing a lot, and even had a cat in my lap for a few minutes. I was worried that booking a spot so early in the day would mean they were sleepy, but these are (mostly) young cats so their schedules don't include quite as much sleep. :) I imagine because I booked in the middle of a workday, that's why the place wasn't full (or at least, didn't seem it).

In short: next time I'm in San Francisco, I'll definitely stop by again!
author: Rose L.

description: Even though I felt that the cats were over socialized, I think this place has a great vibe, awesome waffles and tea, and an opportunity for cat lovers to get some Kitty time.
author: Keerthana K.

description:
KitTea is an adorable cat lounge with the sweetest cats and staff. The entire facility is very clean and beautifully decorated.

You can stay in the Tea Lounge for free and watch the cats and humans play through a glass window, or you can book a reservation online to play with the cats in the Cat Lounge for $25/hr (or $15 for a half hour, but that doesn't seem cost effective). Arrive 5-10 minutes before your reservation time. I recommend the earliest time of 11am so that the cats are fresh and ready to play! 

We had an amazing host. It was obvious he cared about the cats. He also did a great job of making sure we had enough tea and food. The system is so stream-lined, that often your order will be at the window for you to pick up by the time you finish paying for said order (so in what feels like a few seconds!).

I expected all the teas to come in pots, but what we ordered actually came in a single large cup. It's a little pricey at first glance -- $8 -- but this comes with unlimited refills. The matcha cheesecake is delicious. This place is better for a snack rather than a meal.

But on to the more important part -- playing with the cats! The cats are very friendly. However, my main complaint is that there were too many people for the number of cats available.That being said, the staff has done a great job of socializing the cats!

My other complaint, which is by no fault of the cafe, is that people do not seem to understand how to interact with cats, so here are some tips and facts from your resident cat lady to help make your experience more positive!
 - Cats are different from dogs. Duh. It's obvious, but judging by the reviews, people don't understand that. Dogs crave our attention. Cats really don't care and will go wherever they please, including high up on the play structures, far away from us. Be patient!
- Cats sleep up to 16 hours a day, so there's a really high chance of them being asleep when you're visiting. Don't pick them up while they're sleeping. You don't like being woken up from a nap; neither do they. Feel free to pet them gently though!

And all these lovely cats are up for adoption :-)

Don't forget to get a stamp card on your way out!
author: Victoria C.

description:
The cafe and lounge are super cute and every employee we encountered was extremely nice and helpful, but we probably won't be back.

I don't know why this concept works better in Japan but it simply could be that they have more cats per customer. We went at noon on a Saturday and there were 8 people and 4-5 cats. Of those cats, 2 stayed asleep the whole time. Even when the other 3 were awake, how do you fight 6 other people for their attention?

I appreciate how the employees gave us dry food to try and coax the cats, but it didn't help much. Some simply weren't hungry.

Maybe there are animal rights laws preventing them from allowing more cats in the area? Not sure, but for $25/hour it was definitely a let down.
author: Tina G.

description:
I've never been to a cafe like this before and don't own a cat myself so this was an amazing experience in a pretty central part of the city. I went with a group of friends and everyone had a lot of fun interacting with the cats. The free flowing tea was also a nice bonus and the staff were all helpful and courteous and could probably have talked about cats and their personalities all day if you wanted to. 

I'd dock it a star because when we went after lunch, over half the cats were napping and mostly continued to nap throughout the visit and I later figured that there was a big gathering earlier that morning with a cartoon showing and it exhausted the cats. I'm sure the cats would've been more energetic on most other days but all cats seemed a bit subdued when we were there, so it wasn't as special as it could've been. Still had a great time!
author: Kevin K.

description: have been there twice, met and played with so many cute cats, very playful. Great service, super organized, very clean place.
author: Zesi C.

description:
First off Kittea is doing an amazing thing, and it is a great way to socialize cats and to socialize with cats.

However, they really need to work on training their staff to be friendlier to people dropping 300 bucks per hour to have a private party.

My dad and friends are cat obsessed, so we spent his party here. First of all, yes, WAY too expensive considering we even had to get our own food out of the other area.
 
The front desk lady was just plain rude. Seriously. The cat wrangler was OK, but in the middle of playing with a very happy and loving kitten. She just took it out of my wife's hands and said that she would bring in a kitten that was more social. She brought out a scared cat that didn't want to be out to replace the playful, purring, happy cat.

Not to mention that when the food we ordered finally did come out it was the end of the hour, so we got kicked out for the next group to come in. And had to eat our food elsewhere.

We are talking about sandwiches, cookies, and waffles all of which I could make better and faster at home.

In short, great business idea, poor execution, please train your staff how to provide good customer service, especially when you charge so much.
author: Luke A.

description: Had a great time here on the way to the airport with some time to kill; a really relaxing and adorable experience with a bunch of very friendly rescue cats. Went in the afternoon when cats are normally at their sleepiest, but they perked up when we were allowed to hand feed them and got to play with them for a lengthy amount of time. Nice selection of teas, too, and would have loved to get some food from the cafe if I'd had time. Would definitely come back, and it's a great cause to support.
author: Nathaniel T.

description:
I've been waiting for KitTea to open for FOREVER. Youtube videos of people visiting cat cafes in other countries can only satisfy me for so long.

The facility is absolutely lovely. The design is very clean & modern, which I personally enjoy. We had 1 adult cat and 9 kittens on our visit here. They weren't the most active but it was nice just to hold and pet them. For the most part, they were pretty tolerant to being picked up and moved. And even though the employees can't serve you in the cat lounge because of health regulations, you're allowed to bring the food & teas into the lounge yourself.

I love that they work with a local shelter to obtain their kittens. All the ones that you get to play with are up for adoption. According to our cat wrangler, they've already help 20 kittens find their forever homes since they opened.

I would consider this place to be pretty decently priced: $15 for 30mins or $25 for 1hr. The reservations come with unlimited cups of 5 different teas. One hour goes by so quickly in here though. I don't think 30 minutes would have been enough for me! I would recommend placing a reservation if you're coming on a weekend day because we saw some people turned away.

The food (and tea outside of your reservation) is pretty pricey though. We tried all the included teas aside from Happy Tails (the licorice containing one). There's a good enough variety that I think everyone would be able to find something they like. My favorite was Cat Nap which has a light floral taste. As for the food, we only tried the quiche. It was tiny for the price and disappointing taste-wise. It also came out still cold, even top part.

Another downside is that your experience can depend on the other people that you go in with. If everyone is walking around and trying to pet all the cats, it can seem pretty crowded.

I will definitely come back. My visit was probably the highlight of my entire week and was a great way to de-stress.
author: Cammie W.

description: Surprised my hubby on some kitty cuddles. Super successful, he was very excited. Great place to cuddle kitties for those of us who cannot have cats in their apartment :)
author: Nia A.

description: Love, love, love KitTea Cafe!  Staff is kind and informative, and the kitties are well cared for.  I especially like that the cats have a quiet room in the back where they can get away if they need to. Lots of fun play time!
author: Erica W.

description:
A rip off! I have been to cat cafes in Japan and remembered it fondly.  We wanted to recreate the experience on my daughter's birthday for her friends. The first thing we experienced instead when walking in the door was the strong smell of cat poop. When you are paying $100 for 4 people, they should clean the litter boxes before the people are let in.  

In Japan, which has more of space premium that San Francisco, the cat cafes are 3x the size with tracks above to watch the cats.  Here the cats can simply leave the "café" and disappear anytime they want. These are rescued cats and not comfortable with people.  It's dangerous and unfair to put rescue cats in this situation even though I think the owners would say they are "helping" them get "adopted."  For people paying a lot to play with cats its awful because they only interact when you feed them and very little after that.  

The gal "helping" out went on "break" for 10 minutes during the hour and then all the cats disappeared.  My 3 girls with me were bored and we left after spending 15 minutes of the hour I paid for.  The owner of the café was rude to me initially when I asked to just reserve a  1/2 hour because we had many stops on a limo trip.  I moved everything around so we could spend 45 minutes there and it was a big disappointment for my dauguhter's only 13th birthday.  Clearly the focus here is to appeal to people who don't know that this café is subpar although others were wondering where the cats went.  Maybe a few tourists and have single visitors but not the way these cafes are the rage in Japan, have lots of varied and fun cats and cost  1/2 the price.  Skip this "attraction" visit a shelter or Japan instead.  Hopefully a competitor will soon do it better because if this was good then $25 would be worth it but clearly the focus is not on the cats or the customers just making money.
author: Karie K.

description:
This kind of business is the one of those business that are the outcome of a "feel-good" economy. Overpriced green tea to hang out with cats? seriously?hysterical. I made an appointment with my friend to come here and I wish we didn't at all, the cats are cute but charging for me to play with the cat is ridiculous + overpriced green tea = no sir,not coming back again. You could tell the place is starting to lose it's hype because not everyone is ready to burn $50 on a place like this.

Next, please.
author: Sarah N.

description: I used to live in Japan where Cat Cafes are quite trendy, but since being back in the States, they are hard to come by, so I consider myself lucky to have found this one! While the entire concept of cats paired with tea is already completely adorable, this particular shop is a peach! From the website to the gift shop, everything is well put-together and exceptionally organized. The cats were playful and the tea was delightful. The actual cat room was a bit hot for my liking, and I'd prefer to be in there with fewer people next time, but overall, the experience was fantastic. Also, the cost is not at all "too pricey." You're basically making a $20 donation to a cat shelter in exchange for cat snuggles and unlimited, high-quality tea. People complaining about that probably aren't cat people anyway, so who cares about them anyway? 10/10 highly recommend, would do again.
author: Tara A.

description: My husband is a cat affectionado  so this was perfect for him.  We don't like Green tea that much, so I ordered coffee for us to have while we play with and petted the cats.. The coffee was terrible and priced to high ... They should go to Pete's and get some better beans.
author: Christine D.

description:
Pleasant, courteous and helpful staff provided us a great environment to interact and play win cats and kittens. 

Tea was provided which was really great. It's more than just the normal Japanese green tea. There were 5 flavors that had a calming effect when drunk. 

Overall we had a fun and great experience and would return in the near future!
author: Josh P.

description:
What an innovative business that satisfies people's love for cats and brings about adoption of cats. For $15, that goes to pet charity, one can sit and play with the cats for 30 minutes while sipping a cup of tea. There are toys the cats can play with and floor cushions to sit on to get on the same level as the cats. The thrust is to get people to adopt, but for me, a person with cat allergies, KitTea allows me to play with cats while not actually adopting one. There is a stamp card that tracks your visits and after 10 visits, you get a free visit.
Also, there is a viewing room. If you don't want to actually go in and play with the cats, you can sit and have a delicious scone and tea while watching the cats through a window. It is a fun experience!
author: Marc U.

description: Loved the concept and getting to love on all the kitties. A lot of them were sleeping and tucked away but as soon as the "cat wrangler" got some treats they all perked up right away. I could see though how it wouldn't be as great if there was a larger group of people in the room with you. Loved how different all the cat's attitudes were. I will say however that the tea that comes with the visit was pretty awful. I think it was worth every penny, I just wish it would never end!
author: Ashley U.

description: wonderful staff, clean space, yoga practice felt very relaxing and the instructor was great, cats are adorable... what more could you want?
author: Susie K.

description:
Super friendly staff, friendly cats, beautiful atmosphere, bottomless tea service, etc. 

Perfect for anyone who loves tea & kittens. 
I recommend make a reservation beforehand only because it could get quite busy in the afternoon and the space is limited!! My friend and I arranged our visit for the first hour of opening so it wasn't too crowded 

They also have events like yoga with the kittens and movie nights with the kittens! (By reservation, I believe for both events) 

Pricey-- being about $25/1hr per person, but I absolutely would visit again!
author: Yabut A.

description: We went to the cafe while on vacation. Me and my daughter loved it. We don't have one at home yet and she lives kitties. First time we ever tried Japanese tea and it was good
author: Melissa C.

description:
Uhhh, I mean how can say anything bad about this place... Oh wait, you can't! Tea and Pussy, that's all you need in life. 

You're in a warm room, with warm kitties and warm tea or cold, if you're a weirdo ;-) Hardy-Har. 

This place is not cheap but I suppose it's worth the price. You either can get a 30-minute session or an hour. Clearly thirty minutes is not enough. It's true: Time flies when you're having fun. The room is full of (I think) 8-12 cats. It's a combo of cats and kittens. You can drink tea in the kitty room but no food. There are lots of toys, lots of tea (all you can drink) and no more than 8 other patrons. Then one staff member there to facilitate and take your tea orders. 

I've been a few times (yes, a FEW) and I admit, that some of the employees are more fun than others and it changes the whole experience. I'm not going to call anyone out because don't get me wrong, the staff is kind and nice and inviting buuut some have a little more energy and panache, which can make playtime with the kitties a tad funner. Is funner a word? It always sounds weird when I wrote it, grammatically. Hmmm anyway- I digress, talking about pussies... all the fur balls are adoptable. That's awesome. Kind of get to test drive or try the milk before buying the cow. Although, don't dilly dally because the turnover seems to be fairy consistent. 

If you're going for just a fun time, it's great. If you're going to check out kitty prospects, it's great. If you're going to pick yourself up after a long/hard/tough/didn't pet enough office animals day, it's great. So DO IT, go. You can thank me later or now. 

They also have food but I can review that yet because nothing has gone in this mouth yet. Possibly my next visit. It'll happen. Just wait. I know you're on the edge of your seat.
author: Erika M.

description: Cats, tea, what more do you need!! Little expensive but the cats are nice
author: Ash C.

description: Had lots of fun with the cats. Very friendly atmosphere. My child loved it.
author: Julieny R.

description: my second time there amd I loved it. i sent my son there, too and he really had a great time since he can't have a cat where be lives. i appreciate what you do an am happy to support you!
author: Sylvia H.

description: Very knowledgeable staff. Great friendly cats. Would visit again.
author: Carla B.

description: Fun hour to leave your phones to the side and focus on some cats...selection of green tea was great from traditional style to some more unique flavors.
author: Alan M.

description: Fantastic place! I took my 9 year old son and we had a great time. The cats are wonderful and the staff too. We even cane back and hung out in the cafe. Wonderful food and drinks! I'm definitely coming back
author: Traci R.

description:
I love me some kitties, teas, and puns and so KitTea is purrrty much a dream come true! 
$25 for 1 hour of playtime with 4-5 magnificent furbabies that are up for adoption whilst sipping bottomless Japanese teas (pinkies up). I left KitTea feeling super relaxed with a case of the warm and fuzzies. It was complete zen petting magical cat bellies and snuggling with the kitties just lion around.  

Dem Kittehs!
My inner cat lady shined as I gave all the pettings to the sweet purrrbabies. The kitties range in temperament, energy, age, and sociability and amazingly all get along with each other and the hoomans! The cat room is equipped with some rad cat toys and furniture (from a hamster wheel to laser pointers to Valerian root chew toys). It's a kitty playground or in many cases a snooze zone. 

The Space
There are 2 main rooms and 1 back room.
The Tea Room/Cafe - Where you can hangout, drink tea, and order snacks.
The Cat Room - You are required to hand sanitize and stay in the cat room during the full hour. You can also order tea and snacks and get refills of tea if you so choose. There are about 6-8 hooman visitors at a time and 1 Cat Wrangler KitTea worker. The ambiance is relaxing with soothing music playing in the background and kitties roaming around or sleeping. The hour sure goes by fast and it's great to hear that many cats have already been adopted!

There is a back room where new kitties can get acclimated and lots of litter boxes for the kitties to do their business and a bathroom for the hoomans. 

The KitTeaM
The KitTea Team (KitTeam) are welcoming, attentive, and warm! We arrived before our appointment and were given nice hand-crafted ceramic tea mugs and a choice of 2 herbal teas or 3 caffeinated teas from Japan. We hung out in the proper cafe area and were given a sample of the Sakura tea special. The Cat Wrangler knows all the cats by name as well as their personalities and there is also a kitty lookbook with bios of all of the cats that are up for adoption. The KitTeam sure did do a great job designing the place and the customer experience. I love the attention to detail - the fun punny website, the local cat wall art, the cute teapots and tea cups, bag and coat check-in, and providing lint rollers. 

I'm pretty much hooked on KitTea and can't wait to fill up my frequent visitor card.
Meow I can express my inner cat lady without the stigma of actually being one!
author: Angela C.

description: I went to Kittea Cafe because I will be looking into adopting a cat in the new year and had no idea if I was allergic to them! So I decided to test it out here. Good news, I am not allergic, so I will be looking into saving a cat soon! But I was also very impressed with the space. In addition to testing out my allergies to the cats, I wanted to see how the place smelled and how the shedding situation was. I was a firm Cat nay sayer in the past so I wanted to test out my misconceptions. I was very pleased, it smelled very clean in the cat lounge and since the cats were well groomed there wasn't much shedding going on and I didn't see one hairball on the floor. two thumbs up. looking forward to adopting a cat!
author: Darine V.

description: Cute place. Tasty treats. Lots of cats! Many cats were sunning themselves in the nook at the window and another group of people stayed there most of the time, giving no access to other people. The cat wrangler was good about creating interaction by getting treats for us to give cats, adding or removing cat toys, etc.
author: Sandra L.

description: My daughter and I had a great time, from the moment we walked in, we were greeted very warmly. The employees in the the tea lounge were helpful and nice. Once in cat room were given the rules and than we enjoyed playing , feeding, relaxing with the cats. KitTea takes very good care of their cats. They are trained and very loved. Our "catress" was very knowledgeable. She made us feel very comfortable. We truly enjoyed our time. Wish it was longer cause it was that nice. We will definitely be back for some of their other activities nights they have. Love the concept of this business!! Oh... and the warmed toilet seat was an amazing surprise
author: Katrina R.

description: Love!!  Kitties! My first time at any kind of cat cafe.  We arrived for a noon booking on a Friday and I was so excited to get in there.  An hour goes by pretty fast!  Most of the kitties wanted to nap when we were in there because the previous group of guests tired them out. So I would suggest coming in the morning when they are awake and playful. They were super friendly though and not shy.  The kittens were so fun! Love the great play area they have there.
author: Christine V.

description: I have been here 3 times now. My first 2 times were amazing and I had an incredible time. But the last time I was there, they actually sold treats to give to the cats. Now if you think about it, if one person has a thing of treats and one person does not, that person without treats does not get any kitty love. Also, all those treats being put into those kitty bellies all day long is not good for them as were exhibited by two cats throwing up while we were. We also found out that the cats aren't up for adoption like before. I'd rather go to Oakland next time where cats needs homes at Cat Town.
author: Theodore S.

description: Had a great time watching Caturday Morning Cartoons with the kitties!
author: Frances T.

description:
Cute and amazing cat cafe. Took my boyfriend here for his surprise belated birthday date and he absolutely loved it.

The aethestics are amazing and simple. The teas were brewed freshed. The employees were knowledgeable about the cats. You can tell that they care about their feline residents.

There were a lot of kittens up for adoptions and some older cats, too. They were all cute and friendly. If I did not have a canine, I would have adopted one of the older cats. But you can tell that they love it there. 

5 out 5 for the asthetics, menu, ambience, and staff. Amazing.
author: Dani D.

description: Nice place, but alright price-- 30 minutes for $14 and on weekends an hour is $28 (per person) but Monday Wednesday and Friday is $15 per hour though. The hourly sessions come with complementary tea. Cats are super cute and staff are friendly!
author: Connie H.

description: This place is a refuge for felines and humans alike. A warm, comforting atmosphere complete with a selection of green teas makes this cat cafe a destination for cat lovers and animal lovers alike. If everyone got along as well as these cats do, it would be a peaceful world.
author: Hannah H.

description:
Although the idea is charming and unique, the actual experience is not so much. It's a bit overpriced for the novelty experience. The tea selection was fair enough, and included refills, but for the admission price to the cat area, it would've been nice to include a scone. (we paid $17 for 3 scones, on top of the $20 admission fee.  The cafe menu is a  bit eclectic , even strange (salmon and goat cheese waffle wrap ?) and is NOT good for anyone with dietary restrictions due to food sensitivities. My husband had to take my daughter down the block, to get a gluten-free, no cheese pizza.

The actual cafe is TINY,  and they cram 9-10 guests in there until the KitTea cat room scheduled appointment time, (along with any walk-in patrons to the cafe). There's only seating for 8 at small tables-for-two, and a counter that seats maybe 4 more...

The cat room is also pretty small, which is why they limit the number of guests at each session, but we were stepping over one another (they encourage you to get down on the floor to play with the cats) and many of the cats were not interested in engaging with humans.  Only about 5 cats were actively moving about the room, so guests were vying for their attention. 

What I do like is that they work to adopt out cats, and have adopted out 176 cats to date in the two years of operation. Interacting with the cats, allows one to get a feel for the personality of each. The Staff clearly love the cats there , and it is evident that the resident cats also love the Staff.

I took two cat-crazy girls (both 17) here for the experience, and they did indeed state that it was their favorite part of the day in SF, but the plan was to have lunch there They did not like the menu selection, so instead of having lunch, we ended up just having tea and scones, and getting lunch somewhere else.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I got a gift of Cats on Mats (yoga with cats) for Valentine's day. The place is small but so cozy and welcoming. I got a free cup of green tea with the yoga. It was delicious. The barista was so nice, she offered to make a cup of the kind they were currently out of. They sell all kinds of kitty stuff, trinkets and socks. They also offer food in the cafe, it looked like waffles and sandwiches. The cafe also offers a glass wall that looks into the cat room, so if you a rent actually going in, you can eat/drink and watch the cats. Only about 7 people are booked for the Yoga at a time. Yoga time was in the cat room. ALL SUPPLIES ARE SUPPLIED. You don't need to bring anything besides a fun attitude and love of cats. There were about 10 cats I think. They were all very friendly. The yoga instructor was also very good. She asked if anyone had sore spots or ailments that could keep them from doing certain moves and she asked if it was ok to touch is during certain things. Very professional. It also wasn't super advanced, so all levels can participate. There was lots of cat related hilarity. After yoga is over you can stay and let/play with the cats for a bit.

All in all 10/10 would recommend.
author: Monica C.

description:
KitTea is a fantastic, unique, place to hangout with some cats and have a cup of tea. 

Tea --  big selection of asian teas, served in ceramic cups -- you get as many refills as you want with your appointment booking fee

Food --  a light menu of snacks and lunch/brunch items. We ordered some snacks on a whim, and the cookies were so-so but the spinach feta quiche is some of the best quiche I've ever had! 

Cats --  a never ending mix of adoptable, social, cats of all breeds, ages, and personalities. A big thing people should know before going is that the cats are... cats; there's no promise they'll want to be petted, play, or even been seen with you. KitTea has really cool wall boxes the cats can climb up into, beds and boxes under the bench seating, and a quiet area the cats can retreat into if they want to sleep or just be alone. 

The decor is gorgeous and there's also a separate cafe area with a huge window to the cat area you can visit anytime without an appointment if you just want some tea and snacks, or to sit down and work a while.

Most importantly, your $25/hr fee goes to animal adoption and shelters and it looks like they're getting shelter cats into forever homes week after week, which is great. It can be really hard to get older or adult cats homes, but KitTea is helping to solve that problem!
author: Laura J.

description: The staff was friendly and so were the cats. Our visit was all we expected and we thoroughly  enjoyed visiting with some cats. We were out of town and missing our cats at home. What a fun experience. I hope the black female gets adopted to a loving home real soon.
author: L. Ruth A.

description: Overpriced.. and cats are sleeping(you can't touch them while they sleep) in order for cats to be your friend you have to buy a 2$ snack.. after 14$ for 30min and plus tea(about 12$)
author: Lana S.

description:
My friend couldn't go to her reservation, so she sent the staff an email and my boyfriend and I went instead! They have a small selection of teas; we got the sencha and hojicha, both were very nice.

We sat in a small room, about 10 people total, with the cats. The cats were a big mix - two kittens and six or so adult cats, all with different personalities. We took some photos and there were lots of toys and towers for the cats to play with. They also provided a book with the names of each cat and some helpful descriptions of each of their personalities. An hour was a purr-fect amount of time to spend with the cats, and they let us in when we got there ~ 10 minutes early.

I did get scratched by one of the cats, but I've gotten much worse from my own cat, and the employees moved the cat into another room (she seemed tired/stressed) and gave me antiseptic and a bandaid.

A very therapeutic hour. They also have stamp cards!
author: Gigi G.

description: Love this place! Cute kitties and great tea, what more can you ask for? The staff are super informative about each kitty and we're super accommodating. Definitely need to book in advance as it sells out frequently but worth it. Can't wait to try their movie and yoga events.
author: Ranee W.

description: OVERPRICED. The cats were nice. The staffs customer service was subpar and the drinks were poorly made.
author: Melody M.

description: well, the cafe inside is pretty cute. but the room for playing with cats are kinda small. And they let people in as a group for one hour session. It is kinda awkward for us with all strangers in the same little room and people waiting outside can see us through the window...
author: Zhi Z.

description:
What a lovely idea! I had so much fun. Can't wait to come back.
It's a great way to meet potential cat-mates while enjoying a nice cup of tea and a delicious scone.
author: Emily C.

description: I come here as often as I can to play with the cats and drink the incredible tea. The cats are very well taken care of, and I love the care that's gone into the space - Courtney, the owner, clearly puts a lot of love into the business and runs things very ethically. The tea quality is much higher than Samovar, and I'm totally addicted to their Matcha (best one I've been able to find so far in the city).
author: Cari L.

description: This place is amazing! Went here last week (me and my brother) and it was a great time.  I live in an apartment nearby that doesn't allow cats, an this gave me what i wanted.  The staff is super friendly and the whole setup is really unique and interesting.  One thing that really stood out to me is that everything was so humane towards the cats.  I know a lot of people who could learn a thing or two of how to care for kittens from this place.  And the staff definitely loves cats!  The tea was great, too! I got coffee, myself, but my brother raved about the tea. Will come again!
author: Sam A.

description: Cute novel idea.  I am not so into cats, but if you like kitties or maybe are dating someone who likes kitties, this is a a cool option.  The coffee is meh, but there are some yummy fudge treats to enjoy while watching kitties ignore humans.  They do a pretty good job of keeping the place well ventilated, but my nose felt a little itchy.  The employees give off a slightly pretensions hipster vibe which is a turn off for me, but I imagine most will feel right at home.  Down with the fact that  they help cats find homes.
author: Chelsey G.

description: I would definitely recommend KitTea! I came on a Monday afternoon and it was such a delightful and relaxing experience. Everything was top notch. The staff were attentive and friendly. The pour-over coffee was excellent. The space was clean and inviting. I didn't have any food, but the waffles looked absolutely delicious. Oh, and the cats! The cats were wonderful and very sweet. Cats can be skittish, but these ones were very friendly and liked to be held. Oh, and they have one of those fancy toilets with a warm seat! I will be back!
author: Ramona E.

description: This is the most zen place in SF. My friend and I went for our birthdays--what better way to spend a midday birthday day than drinking tea and petting kitties? Super sweet. Can't wait to bring my kids and my parents.
author: Medeab B.

description: Had an amazing time here- staff was very friendly, cat cafe had a peaceful yet playful vibe. Would highly recommend to any animal lover!
author: Liz P.

description:
Over all a unique and fun spot to experience something new in SF. 

I took my husband here for his Birthday he is a cat lover, but I am very allergic. He had a great time despite the really awkward people in the cat lounge with us and the snooty guy that greeted us when we came in. Our cat wrangler was sweet and helpful and all refreshments were fresh and delicious! We shared a pot of sencha and the fruit and Nutella waffle both good. 

I lasted about 45 minutes inside the cat lounge before I had to step into the tea lounge, which is not bad for me even though I had taken allergy medicine. I probably would have lasted longer but I went into a corner were they had books and extra cat toys which just so happens to be the dustiest spot. Its also a bit stuffy and small inside, but you can't ask for a ton of space in SF. 

I wanted to buy a few items in the front gift shop area, but the unhelpful attitude of the guy up front just made me want to leave. He made it seem like a major chore when I asked him for extra shirt sizes and it seemed like he just didn't want to be there. 

We may go back since its one of the few places to get a good cat fix. Just wish we had a better first time experience!
author: Auji P.

description:
**This is only a review of the adoption process (or I guess, lack thereof) handled by Kittea and their partnering animal shelter, Wonder Cat Rescue.** 

Long story short, I saw that Kittea had a new pair of brothers and was looking into adopting them even before they were socialized and allowed to play in the main cafe. I feel like I did my part to communicate with both Kittea and Wonder Cat Rescue, but ended up missing out on the opportunity to even meet them. (If you want the full play-by-play of my experience with Wonder Cat Rescue, you can read it here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/wonder-cat-rescue-san-francisco?hrid=MaTBxI8Pf6aAcEX3xV5b2w)

The cats at Kittea are provided by a local animal rescue center called Wonder Cat Rescue, which is mainly run by one person who I think (from reading other reviews) does so in her spare time. Super kudos to her for trying to provide for and find homes for tons of animals. The issue with this is that the service and attention available falls short of a good experience - and this is doubly true now that Kittea is open for business. There are now more cats on display to potential owners, and given the popularity of Kittea ("the first cat cafe in San Francisco"), I suspect the turnover must be high. 

Now, I fully understand that you can't put cats "on hold" if you're not able to immediately meet and adopt them during the week, especially when the kittens in question are as adorable as the ones in question. But Wonder Cat Rescue should have been upfront about there being other people meeting them before me so I knew that 1) I was the "backup" 2) I should allocate my time to looking at other shelters. I initially inquired about and sent in an adoption form for the kittens on Monday (having sent in a general application to Wonder Cat Rescue a whole month prior and never hearing back) and was told to check back on Thursday. I did and got no response. Nothing on Friday or Saturday, either. I get an email on Sunday saying they've been adopted.

I had swapped a handful of emails with Wonder Cat Rescue on Monday and Tuesday, and in that following Thursday-Saturday period, I did my due diligence and emailed Wonder Cat Rescue again, as well as called and left voice messages with Kittea. I even messaged them on Facebook inquiring about the kittens' availability. By Sunday, I wasn't expecting a response from Kittea at all but I actually got a FB message on Monday saying that they had been adopted, and that they aren't able to check their voicemail all the time so I should've emailed instead. If that's the case then perhaps you shouldn't put "If you have any questions call us at 415-658-7888" on your website and then never pick up.

This review isn't about missing out on the kittens so much as how there wasn't satisfactory communication with Kittea (it's also hard to separate the experience between the two entities). Courtney, the founder of Kittea, responded to my follow-up FB messages and tried to explain that they can't "cherry pick" who gets to meet the cats meaning they can't put them on hold. Yes, I get that, and I already said so. I'm glad the kittens were able to find a good home, and I don't have negative feelings about that. It's the fact that there is a presumption that I actually don't understand all that and the absence of transparency about the adoption process (which is something hopefully Kittea and Wonder Cat Rescue will work on together). I feel like my time was devalued.

Again, this is a review solely on my attempt to meet and potentially adopt the cutest (read: in the highest demand) pair of kittens from Kittea. I'm not sure I have any advice for other potential owners as I felt like I did all I could do in my situation of not being able to meet the kittens ASAP.

Edit: Changing my review to a 1-star. I was on Instagram and saw that the brothers had actually been adopted separately, when the Kittea website stated they had to be adopted together. So Wonder Cat Rescue decided to split the siblings up rather than wait a few extra days for a willing home that could take in both of them... Strange. So much for doing "what's best for the cats".
author: Katie M.

description: Fabulous experience.  Grateful there is a home for these cats.
author: Sharon J.

description:
I'm not super obsessed with cats or anything, so maybe if you're a big cat lover you'd give this place 5 stars. I really enjoyed my time here though and I think it's a fun activity to do. 

The place is pretty clean and I like that they're giving little kittens a new home. :) 
The tea was probably my favorite part. They have a lot of different options and you can get a flight to try all of them. They also have some food options for purchase as well. I didn't have any food when I was there so I can't comment on taste. 

The kittens were adorable. I wish they were more playful though...it was towards the end of the afternoon so they could have been tired from all the cuddling they did earlier in the day. It was a fun and unique way to spend my Saturday afternoon, but I got kind of bored at the end. I wish there was something I could have done with them other than just pet them! I understand that's probably not realistic though.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: The cat lounge was well furnished and had plenty of seating for both guests and cats. All the cats were friendly and some would even sit in your lap on their own. You're allowed to pick the cats up here which is different from other cat cafes I've been to. It was overall a fun experience and a relaxing way to spend an hour of your day.
author: Michelle C.

description: Was here Aug. 27 at end of the day. All the cats were residents, not adoptable, and could care less about having visitors. They ignored all of us, in fact. As my teenage son put it: "The cats are like burned-out retail employees." I cannot recommend the experience I had but if they have more adoptable cats in the future, maybe they'd be more interested in visitors.
author: Amy L.

description: I loved going to KitTea! The cats were so sweet, and the layout with food and tea on 1 side, and cats on the other was perfect. Also, great merchandising- perfect for gifts, little treasures, or just something fun for yourself. Really beautiful layout, wish I had taken photos. I will definitely be back soon!
author: L H.

description: We spent a fabulous hour with the kitties today. My daughters snuggled, played and loved their way through the hour. Feeding the cats snacks was hilarious. So much fun!
author: Tracey P.

description:
The Cool Concept of a kitten cafe just arrived in San Francisco! Been constantly reminded for a visit by the lady and decided to come here on Valentine's Day Eve (Saturday)! Made a reservation online for a 7pm-8pm appointment which came out to be $52 for 2 people (25 per person per hour + 2 fees on weekends and 20 per person per hour + 2 fees on weekdays) The price seems pretty steep for just petting kittens especially if you live with cats.... it just doesn't seem like a great deal to pay excess amount but at least the mission of the cafe is to find these kittens a home and up for an adoption! Parking is very limited in this district so you're probably gonna end up parking at a meter or some tight alley praying that you don't hit the cars around you. (Public transportation highly recommended) 

Entering the petite cafe it seemed like a peaceful environment kind of like a library. There's a room to get your tea (selected teas included with reservation) and the door thats kept closed to enter the room with the kittens. It's a shoes off policy which are kept in a mini basket prior to entry. There were maybe like 8 kittens approximately roaming around and 2 in a glassed room because they were too young and vulnerable to come out but you can make an entry to the glassed room with request and hand sanitization! My favorite kitten was Pocket (black petite kitten)  who was originally asleep when arriving but she shot up to be somewhat energetic. I felt like at the time of 7pm.... most of the kittens were some what tired because of the long day as a few were little bit sleepy on and off. There were maybe 12 total people in the room during the one hour duration  so theres plenty of room and not crowded at all. There was an instructor (forgot his name) that introduced the cats and helped with the cat interactions! 

I believe our time slot of 7-8pm was indeed the last reservation before it closed as we saw them tidying the place up! Cool concept to experience once but i don't know if i would go back again just because of the steep price.. and I personally allergic to cats as well as more interested in puppies! There are...I believe goat and puppies cafe in Korea which seem more appealing! i shall visit those on my visit to Korea!! 

Be prepared to be itchy if you're allergic!!
author: Auden W.

description: My husband and I love KitTea! Not only because we love cats, but because we think that what KitTea is doing is an awesome and unique way to help cats get adopted! We had waffles and tea from the Cafe which were great! The staff is friendly, knowledgeable about the cats and passionate about what they are doing! When I was there they had 114 cats adopted from them and I know it has increased since then! Even if you aren't in the market for a pet, it is a great place to go and give the cats some love! Keep up the good work, KitTea!
author: Rachel M.

description: What a great place! Fantastic service, fantastic food, fantastic drinks, neat merch, and an awesome atomosphere. Also the waffles are
author: Zachary D.

description: Not sure what these recent negative reviews are talking about. I've been to KitTea several times of late, each with different people, and the uniform response has been enjoyment and a desire to return. This establishment has adorable cats, good food and tea, and a staff that is both courteous and professional. What more could you want!? All in all, this is a clean, well-run, cool place perfect for a variety of occasions.
author: Alexander E.

description: A super enjoyable way to spend an hour with some very playful and sweet cats.  I took my 12-year old cat-loving son, and we both commented how quickly the time went by, interacting with all the furry friends.  Despite being 10 am, most of the cats were very active, and ready to play with the various cat toys.  Adam, the "cat wrangler" was a great host, sharing information about each cat, and guiding play and interaction based on his knowledge of the individual cats' behaviors.  The café was nice, with plenty of offerings, and the ordering and service were deftly handled without missing out on cat-time. Reservations and instructions upon entering were simple, and there are lots of really cool cat items to purchase in the gift shop.  Highly recommended for those who love cats!
